This result helps to disentangle the security assumptions of quantum and classical cryptography.

Title: A Comprehensive Survey on the Implementations, Attacks, and Countermeasures of the Current NIST Lightweight Cryptography Standard
content: This 2023 paper is the first comprehensive survey dedicated to ASCON, the cryptographic suite standardized by NIST in 2023 as the new standard for lightweight cryptography. Lightweight cryptography is a subfield focused on developing cryptographic algorithms that are secure yet efficient enough to run on resource-constrained devices, such as RFID tags, embedded sensors, and IoT devices. The survey provides a thorough review of the ASCON family of algorithms. It covers various hardware and software implementations, analyzing their performance in terms of speed, power consumption, and memory footprint. It also systematically catalogues known attacks against ASCON, including side-channel attacks (which exploit physical information leakage like power consumption) and fault injection attacks. Finally, the paper reviews proposed countermeasures to defend against these attacks, providing a complete, state-of-the-art overview of the security and implementation landscape for this important new cryptographic standard.

Title: How much can ChatGPT really help Computational Biologists in Programming?
content: This 2023 paper investigates the practical influence—both positive and negative—of using ChatGPT for programming tasks specific to the field of computational biology. The authors use a series of illustrative examples to explore a range of use cases. These include using ChatGPT for writing new code for bioinformatics analyses, reviewing existing code for errors or improvements, debugging code that is not working correctly, converting code between different programming languages (e.g., Python to R), refactoring code to make it more efficient or readable, and creating complex data analysis pipelines. The paper aims to provide a balanced perspective, highlighting how tools like ChatGPT can accelerate development and lower the barrier to entry for complex coding tasks, while also pointing out potential pitfalls, such as generating incorrect or inefficient code, and the importance of domain expertise for validating the model's output. The work serves as a practical guide for computational biologists looking to incorporate large language models into their coding workflow.

Title: Recent Breakthrough in AI-Driven Materials Science
content: This 2024 paper highlights two landmark achievements in late 2023 that signify a breakthrough in AI-driven materials science. The first is the unveiling of GNoME (Graph Networks for Materials Exploration) by DeepMind. GNoME is a powerful AI model that was used to computationally discover over 381,000 new, stable crystalline materials. This represents a massive expansion of the known landscape of stable materials, which could have profound implications for technologies like batteries, solar cells, and superconductors. The second breakthrough, announced just days later, was Microsoft's release of MatterGen, a generative AI model for materials science. Unlike GNoME, which primarily predicts stability, MatterGen can generate novel material structures based on desired target properties. For example, a researcher could ask MatterGen to design a new material with a specific conductivity or hardness. Together, these two models demonstrate the transformative potential of AI to accelerate the materials discovery and design cycle, moving the field from slow, trial-and-error experimentation to rapid, in-silico innovation.

Title: Towards Foundation Models for Materials Science: The Open MatSci ML Toolkit
content: This 2023 manuscript reviews recent progress in the development of the Open MatSci ML Toolkit, a framework designed to facilitate research into 'foundation models' for materials science. Foundation models are large-scale machine learning models pre-trained on vast amounts of data, which can then be fine-tuned for a wide range of downstream tasks. This paper details a series of experiments conducted using the toolkit that lay the groundwork for future foundation model research and development in this domain. The authors likely describe the architecture of their toolkit, the types of materials data it is designed to handle (e.g., crystal structures, chemical compositions, properties), and the pre-training objectives used. The ultimate goal is to create a versatile, open-source framework that enables the materials science community to build and utilize powerful, general-purpose AI models to accelerate the discovery and design of new materials.

Title: AI Index Report 2025
content: This resource is a placeholder for a future report. The abstract indicates the 2025 AI Index report will be the most comprehensive to date. It will feature in-depth analyses of the evolving landscape of AI hardware, including novel estimates of the costs associated with AI model inference (the process of using a trained model to make predictions). Additionally, the report will present new analyses of trends in AI-related publications and patenting activity, providing a data-driven overview of the state of artificial intelligence research, development, and commercialization. No further content is available for summarization.

Title: Information-Theoretic Foundations for Machine Learning
content: This 2025 research paper proposes a new theoretical framework for understanding machine learning, rooted in the principles of Bayesian statistics and Shannon's information theory. The authors aim to create a general framework that can unify the analysis of many different phenomena observed in machine learning, such as generalization, overfitting, and the role of model complexity. The core of their framework characterizes the performance of an 'optimal Bayesian learner.' By applying concepts from information theory, such as entropy and mutual information, they likely derive bounds and relationships that connect the amount of information in the training data, the complexity of the model, and the expected performance on new, unseen data. This work seeks to provide a more fundamental, first-principles understanding of the learning process, moving beyond empirical observations to a more rigorous mathematical foundation.

Title: Culturally Aware and Adapted NLP: A Taxonomy and a Survey of the State of the Art
content: This 2025 paper addresses the important and growing area of culturally aware and adapted Natural Language Processing (NLP). The authors argue that most NLP models are trained on data that reflects a narrow range of cultural perspectives, leading to biases and poor performance when applied to diverse populations. Drawing on prior research in NLP and related fields like sociology and linguistics, the paper makes two main contributions. First, it proposes a fine-grained taxonomy of elements in culture (e.g., social norms, values, communication styles) that are relevant to language. This taxonomy provides a systematic framework for analyzing and understanding cultural dimensions in text. Second, the paper presents a comprehensive survey of the state-of-the-art in culturally aware and adapted NLP, using the proposed taxonomy to organize and categorize existing research. The work aims to provide a structured overview of the field and guide future research towards developing more equitable and culturally competent language technologies.

Title: Overview of the NLPCC 2025 Shared Task: Gender Bias Mitigation Challenge
content: This 2025 paper provides an overview of a shared task organized for the NLPCC 2025 conference, focusing on the challenge of mitigating gender bias in text. The shared task poses three specific sub-challenges to participating research teams, requiring their models to automate the entire bias mitigation pipeline. The first challenge is to **detect** the presence of gender bias within a given text. The second is to **classify** the type of bias present (e.g., stereotyping, unequal representation). The third and final challenge is to **mitigate** the detected bias by rewriting the text to be more neutral or equitable. The paper presents the dataset created for this challenge, the evaluation metrics used to score the participating systems, and a summary and analysis of the results achieved by the teams. This shared task aims to spur research and benchmark progress in the important area of automated gender bias mitigation in NLP.

Title: iFormer: Integrating ConvNet and Transformer for Mobile Application
content: This 2025 paper introduces a new family of hybrid neural network architectures for computer vision, called iFormer. These networks are specifically designed for mobile applications, where there is a critical need to balance high accuracy with low latency (fast processing time). The iFormer architecture effectively integrates two types of neural network layers: convolutional layers (from ConvNets) and self-attention layers (from Transformers). The design leverages the respective strengths of each. Convolutional layers are highly efficient at capturing local features and spatial relationships in an image. Self-attention layers excel at modeling long-range dependencies and global context across the entire image. By creating a hybrid that combines the fast local representation capacity of convolution with the efficient global modeling ability of self-attention, iFormer aims to achieve state-of-the-art performance on mobile vision tasks while meeting the strict computational constraints of mobile devices.

Title: Gaze-Guided Learning: Avoiding Shortcut Bias in Visual Classification
content: This 2025 research paper introduces a new approach to combat 'shortcut bias' in visual classification models, motivated by how humans use visual attention. Shortcut bias occurs when a model learns to rely on spurious correlations or simple, non-causal features in the training data (e.g., associating a 'cow' with 'green pasture' instead of the cow's actual features). To address this, the authors make two main contributions. First, they introduce **Gaze-CIFAR-10**, a new dataset that augments the standard CIFAR-10 image dataset with human gaze time-series data, showing exactly where humans look and in what sequence when identifying an object. Second, they propose a **dual-sequence gaze encoder**, a neural network architecture that models this precise sequential localization of human attention on distinct local attributes. By guiding the model to focus on the same salient features that humans use, the proposed 'Gaze-Guided Learning' method aims to correct shortcut biases and encourage the model to learn more robust and generalizable representations.

Title: HumanoidPano: Hybrid Spherical Panoramic-LiDAR Cross-Modal Perception for Humanoid Robots
content: This 2025 paper presents HumanoidPano, a novel perception framework for humanoid robots that addresses key challenges related to their physical structure. Humanoid robots often suffer from severe self-occlusion (where their own limbs block their sensors) and have a limited field-of-view (FOV). HumanoidPano is a hybrid, cross-modal system designed to overcome these constraints by synergistically integrating two different sensing modalities: **spherical panoramic vision** and **LiDAR**. The panoramic camera provides a full 360-degree visual field, eliminating blind spots, while the LiDAR sensor provides precise 3D depth and geometric information about the environment. The framework fuses the data from these two sensors to create a rich, comprehensive representation of the robot's surroundings. This cross-modal approach allows the robot to build a more complete and robust understanding of its environment than would be possible with either sensor alone, improving capabilities like navigation, object recognition, and manipulation.

Title: LLM-Empowered Embodied Agent for Memory-Augmented Task Planning in Household Robotics
content: This 2025 paper describes an advanced system for controlling household robots, empowering them with sophisticated task planning and memory capabilities through the use of Large Language Models (LLMs). The system allows a robot to execute high-level user commands (e.g., 'get me a snack from the pantry') by breaking them down into a sequence of actionable steps. A key feature is its **memory-augmented task planning**, which enables the robot to track its past actions and the state of the environment. This memory is managed using a **Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)** technique, allowing the robot to recall relevant past experiences to inform current decisions. The system's architecture employs three specialized agents, each powered by a task-specific LLM, likely for perception, planning, and action execution. This LLM-empowered embodied agent represents a significant step towards creating more autonomous and capable robots for complex, dynamic household environments.

Title: Peer reviewers from low- and middle-income countries for open access journals in oncology
content: This 2023 paper addresses the challenges and inequities faced by cancer researchers in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). The authors outline several impediments to research and publication from these regions, with a particular focus on the financial barriers posed by Article Publishing Charges (APCs) for open access journals, which are often unaffordable for many researchers in LMICs. The central argument of the paper is that one way to increase diversity, equity, and inclusion in the scholarly publishing ecosystem is to more actively engage peer reviewers from LMICs. The authors contend that involving reviewers from these regions can bring diverse perspectives to the evaluation of research, improve the quality and relevance of published work for a global audience, and help build research capacity and networks within LMICs. The paper advocates for a more inclusive approach to peer review as a step towards a more equitable global oncology research community.

Title: From data strategy to implementation to advance cancer research and cancer care
content: This 2023 paper discusses the critical importance of effective data strategies within a comprehensive cancer center. The authors argue that a systematic approach to data is essential for evaluating clinical practices, deepening the understanding of cancer biology, and ultimately developing better treatments. The paper outlines a multi-faceted data strategy. It begins with **data collection**, emphasizing the need for standardized and high-quality data capture from electronic health records and other sources. It then discusses **data analysis**, highlighting the use of advanced techniques like Natural Language Processing (NLP) to extract valuable information from unstructured clinical notes. Finally, it addresses the importance of **secure data sharing** strategies, which are crucial for enabling collaboration between researchers and institutions while protecting patient privacy. The paper provides a framework for how cancer centers can move from a high-level data strategy to practical implementation to accelerate progress in both cancer research and patient care.

Title: Cardiology researchers' practices and perceived barriers to open science: an international survey
content: This 2024 paper presents the results of an international survey of researchers who publish in cardiovascular journals. The survey was designed to investigate their perceptions, practices, and perceived barriers related to open science. Open science practices include making publications open access, sharing research data, and pre-registering studies. The study aimed to understand the extent to which cardiology researchers are adopting these practices and what factors encourage or hinder their adoption. The key finding of the survey was that **funding** was identified as the most essential incentive to encourage the adoption of open science practices. This suggests that researchers are often willing to engage in open science but are constrained by the costs associated with it, such as article processing charges (APCs) for open access journals and the resources needed to prepare and share data. The findings have important implications for funding agencies, institutions, and publishers seeking to promote open science in the field of cardiology.

Title: Role of open access echocardiography in detection of cardiac structural and functional abnormalities
content: This 2023 study evaluates the clinical utility of an 'open access' echocardiography service, where general practitioners (GPs) can directly refer patients for an echocardiogram (an ultrasound of the heart) without first sending them to a cardiologist. The primary objective was to determine the prevalence of significant structural heart disease in patients referred through this service. The study analyzed referrals from a cohort of late middle-aged patients. The key finding was that major structural and functional cardiac abnormalities are common in this patient population. This result demonstrates the value of open access echocardiography as a diagnostic tool in primary care. It allows for earlier detection of potentially serious heart conditions, which can lead to more timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. The study supports the role of such services in improving the efficiency and effectiveness of cardiovascular disease detection.

Title: Imaging Neuroscience opening editorial
content: This 2023 editorial introduces a new academic journal, *Imaging Neuroscience*. The journal is notable for its origins: it was launched by the former editors of *NeuroImage*, a leading journal in the field, who resigned en masse from their previous positions. The editorial explains that this collective action was a response to what the editors considered to be unethical and unsustainable publication fees charged by the publisher of *NeuroImage*. The new journal, *Imaging Neuroscience*, is established as a non-profit, fully open access publication. The editorial outlines the journal's mission to provide a high-quality, peer-reviewed venue for research in the field of neuroimaging, but with a commitment to fair and affordable publishing practices. This move represents a significant event in the academic publishing world, highlighting the growing tension between commercial publishers and the academic community over the costs of open access.

Title: Open access repository-scale propagated nearest neighbor suspect spectral library for untargeted metabolomics
content: This 2023 paper addresses a key challenge in untargeted mass spectrometry-based metabolomics, a powerful technique for studying the role of small molecules (metabolites) in biological systems. A major bottleneck in this field is the identification of the thousands of unknown compounds detected in a typical experiment. This process, known as metabolite annotation, relies on matching experimental mass spectra to reference spectral libraries. However, existing experimental libraries are limited in size. To overcome this, the authors present a new computational tool: a 'nearest neighbor suspect spectral library.' This library is created by propagating information from existing experimental spectra to chemically similar 'suspect' molecules for which no experimental data exists. This repository-scale library vastly expands metabolite annotation capabilities beyond what is possible with existing experimental libraries alone. The resource is made open access to benefit the entire metabolomics community.

Title: Aerobiology-A New Open Access Journal
content: This 2023 editorial introduces a new scientific journal titled 'Aerobiology'. The journal is launched as a fully open access publication, making all its content freely available to readers worldwide. The editorial outlines the scope and mission of the new journal. Aerobiology is the interdisciplinary study of the airborne dispersal of biological particles, such as pollen, fungal spores, bacteria, viruses, and small insects. The journal will cover research on the processes of particle release, transport, deposition, and their impacts on various systems, including plant pathology, human and animal health (e.g., allergies, infectious diseases), and ecology. The launch of this journal reflects the growing importance and interest in the field of aerobiology, particularly in the context of climate change, global health, and biodiversity.

Title: JASPAR 2024: 20th anniversary of the open-access database of transcription factor binding profiles
content: This 2024 paper provides an update on the JASPAR database, a widely-used, open-access resource in the field of bioinformatics, marking its 20th anniversary. JASPAR is a database of transcription factor (TF) binding profiles. TFs are proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences to regulate gene expression, and their binding profiles (often represented as position frequency matrices) describe their binding preferences. The paper details the 10th release of the database. A key highlight is the significant expansion of the CORE collection, which contains high-quality, curated profiles. In this release, the CORE collection has grown by 329 new profiles, representing a 20% increase over the previous version. This continuous expansion and curation ensure that JASPAR remains a critical and up-to-date resource for researchers studying gene regulation, genomics, and systems biology.

Title: Development of an open access, virtual bioinformatics lab for students in medical laboratory sciences
content: This 2024 paper describes the development and assessment of a novel educational tool: a virtual laboratory learning unit designed to introduce basic bioinformatics concepts and tools to students in medical laboratory sciences (MLS) programs. Recognizing that bioinformatics is becoming increasingly important in clinical diagnostics, the authors created this virtual lab to provide hands-on experience without the need for specialized software or computational infrastructure. The paper details the design of the learning unit, which likely includes modules on sequence alignment, database searching (e.g., BLAST), and interpretation of genomic data. The authors also present the results of their assessment of the unit's effectiveness as a teaching tool. The study concludes that the virtual lab is a promising tool for integrating bioinformatics training into the MLS curriculum. Importantly, the entire learning unit is made available as an open educational resource (OER), allowing other institutions to freely adopt and adapt it.

Title: GetGenome: Overcoming inequalities in access to genomics technology
content: This 2024 article addresses the significant and persistent issue of inequitable access to genomics technology, particularly for researchers in low- and middle-income countries. The authors argue that although genomics has become an integral and transformative part of life science research, its benefits are not being shared globally due to barriers such as cost, infrastructure, and training. The paper introduces GetGenome, a non-profit organization founded to directly tackle this problem. The mission of GetGenome is to provide equitable access to genomics technology, including DNA sequencing and bioinformatics support, to researchers who would otherwise be excluded. In addition to providing access to technology, the organization also focuses on providing training and building local capacity. The article outlines the model and activities of GetGenome, positioning it as a proactive initiative to democratize genomics and foster a more inclusive global scientific community.

Title: Symbiotic revolutions at the interface of genomics and microbiology
content: This 2024 article discusses the evolving understanding of symbiosis, the intimate living together of different species, in light of new genomic technologies. The author notes that symbiosis is an old concept with a contentious history in biology. However, the advent of powerful new genomic and metagenomic sequencing technologies, combined with new research paradigms, is fueling a revolutionary shift in some of the central tenets of the field. These technologies allow scientists to study the genetic makeup of symbiotic partners in unprecedented detail, revealing the intricate molecular and metabolic interactions that underpin these relationships. The author argues that this new data is challenging long-held assumptions and forcing a re-evaluation of concepts related to evolution, individuality, and the very definition of an organism. The article calls for researchers to be 'humble and open-minded about what the data are telling us,' embracing the paradigm shifts that are emerging at the interface of genomics and microbiology.

Title: A novel open-access artificial-intelligence-driven platform for CNS drug discovery utilizing adult zebrafish
content: This 2024 paper presents a novel, open-access platform that uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) for drug discovery related to the Central Nervous System (CNS). The platform is designed to analyze the behavior of adult zebrafish, a powerful model organism in neuropharmacology due to its genetic similarity to humans and transparent body. The system automatically analyzes video tracks of zebrafish movement following treatment with various psychoactive drugs. The core of the platform is an AI system that the authors trained to distinguish between different behavioral patterns induced by these drugs. For example, the AI can learn to identify the characteristic swimming patterns associated with stimulants, sedatives, or anxiolytics. By automating the analysis of these complex behavioral fingerprints, the platform can be used to screen new chemical compounds for potential therapeutic effects on the CNS. The open-access nature of the platform makes this high-throughput screening technology available to the broader research community.

Title: Open Targets Platform: facilitating therapeutic hypotheses building in drug discovery
content: This 2024 paper provides an update on the Open Targets Platform, a major open-source knowledge base designed to support systematic drug target identification and prioritization. The platform integrates a vast amount of data from various sources—including genetics, genomics, and chemical biology—to help researchers generate and evaluate hypotheses about which biological targets (e.g., genes, proteins) are most promising for therapeutic intervention for a given disease. The paper describes recent updates and new features. A key enhancement is a revamp of the 'target-disease associations' page, which is the core of the platform, providing a synthesized view of all evidence linking a target to a disease. Additionally, the authors have added a new 'Target Prioritisation' view, which likely provides tools and visualizations to help users rank and compare potential drug targets based on multiple lines of evidence. These updates aim to make the platform even more powerful and user-friendly for the drug discovery community.

title: Re-emergence of Oropouche virus between 2023 and 2024 in Brazil
summarized_content: This study examines the re-emergence of Oropouche virus (OROV) in Brazil, particularly between 2023 and 2024. It highlights a significant surge in cases, with 81.8% of all laboratory-confirmed infections since 2015 occurring in 2024 alone. The research investigates the virological factors, including viral reassortment and the emergence of a new genotype (genotype Ia), contributing to this outbreak. The paper underscores the need for enhanced genomic surveillance and public health measures to monitor and control the spread of Oropouche fever, which is becoming an increasing public health concern in the Amazon region and beyond.

title: Virulence and transmission vary between Usutu virus lineages in Culex pipiens
summarized_content: This research experimentally compares the vector competence of Culex pipiens mosquitoes for two distinct lineages of the Usutu virus (USUV), EU2 and EU3. The study found significant lineage-specific differences in transmission efficiency and virulence. Mosquitoes infected with the EU3 lineage exhibited higher viral loads in their saliva and a greater transmission rate compared to those infected with the EU2 lineage. Furthermore, the EU3 lineage was associated with higher mortality in the infected mosquitoes, suggesting it is more virulent. These findings indicate that the genetic lineage of USUV plays a crucial role in its transmission dynamics and its potential impact on both vector and host populations.

title: A Survey of Deep Learning and Foundation Models for Time Series Forecasting
summarized_content: This survey reviews the state-of-the-art in deep learning and foundation models for time series forecasting. It highlights how recent architectural advancements, such as transformers, Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), and diffusion models, have demonstrated significant advantages over traditional statistical methods. The paper categorizes models based on their architectural principles and discusses their respective strengths and weaknesses in handling various time series characteristics like seasonality, trend, and non-stationarity. It also explores the emerging paradigm of large pre-trained foundation models for time series, which can perform zero-shot or few-shot forecasting on unseen datasets, concluding that these models represent a promising frontier for the field.

title: LLM-Enhanced Reinforcement Learning: A Survey
summarized_content: This paper provides the first comprehensive survey of the emerging field that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with Reinforcement Learning (RL). It proposes a structured taxonomy to systematically categorize the various ways LLMs can enhance the classical agent-environment RL paradigm. The survey identifies several key roles for LLMs, including acting as a world model, a policy generator, a reward function designer, or an agent component for improved reasoning and planning. The paper reviews current methodologies, discusses key challenges such as grounding and scalability, and outlines promising future research directions at the intersection of these two powerful AI domains.

title: Introduction to Reinforcement Learning
summarized_content: This paper serves as an introductory overview of Reinforcement Learning (RL), a major area of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by performing actions in an environment to maximize cumulative reward. It methodically explains the fundamental components of RL, including states, actions, policies, value functions, and reward signals. The paper covers core methodologies such as dynamic programming, Monte Carlo methods, and temporal-difference learning, and provides a roadmap of key algorithms like Q-learning and SARSA. It is designed to be a foundational resource for newcomers, providing both theoretical concepts and pointers to further learning materials.

title: Variational Quantum Circuits Enhanced Generative Adversarial Network
summarized_content: This paper proposes a hybrid quantum-classical architecture for a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN), termed QC-GAN, aimed at improving the performance of classical GANs. The proposed model features a generator composed of a quantum variational circuit paired with a single-layer classical neural network, while the discriminator is a traditional deep neural network. The quantum circuit is leveraged for its ability to explore high-dimensional Hilbert spaces, potentially enhancing the generator's capacity to learn complex data distributions. The study demonstrates through experiments that the QC-GAN can effectively generate data, suggesting a promising direction for leveraging quantum computing to advance machine learning models.

title: Synthetic Brain Images: Bridging the Gap in Brain Mapping with Generative Adversarial Model
summarized_content: This research investigates the application of Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Networks (DCGANs) for synthesizing realistic Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) slices of the human brain. The primary goal is to address the scarcity of large, publicly available medical imaging datasets, which often hinders the development of deep learning models for medical diagnostics. The generator network is trained on a dataset of real brain scans to learn the underlying data distribution and produce high-fidelity, synthetic images that are difficult to distinguish from real ones. The study demonstrates the potential of this approach to augment medical datasets, thereby improving the training and performance of AI-driven tools for brain mapping and pathology detection.

title: State of Geographic Access to Cancer Treatment Trials in the United States
summarized_content: This study analyzes the geographic accessibility of cancer clinical trials across the United States, revealing significant disparities. The findings indicate that a majority of U.S. counties, particularly those that are nonmetropolitan, have high levels of social vulnerability, or experience high cancer mortality rates, have limited or no access to cancer treatment trials. This lack of local trial availability creates substantial barriers for patients, exacerbates health inequities, and limits the diversity of trial participants. The paper calls for concerted efforts from sponsors and policymakers to facilitate the participation of diverse and geographically distributed sites to promote more equitable access to cutting-edge cancer treatments.

title: Large language models in medicine: A review of current clinical trials
summarized_content: This systematic review analyzes the landscape of current clinical trials investigating the applications of Large Language Models (LLMs) in healthcare. The authors identified 27 registered trials, comprising 5 published and 22 ongoing studies. The applications of LLMs in these trials were categorized into four main areas: direct patient care (e.g., clinical documentation, patient communication), medical data handling, clinical decision support for physicians, and research assistance. The review highlights the growing interest in leveraging LLMs to improve healthcare efficiency and outcomes but also underscores the nascent stage of this research, emphasizing the need for rigorous clinical validation to ensure safety and efficacy.

title: The role of Open Access Data in democratizing healthcare AI
summarized_content: This article argues that Open Access Data is a crucial catalyst for the democratization of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in healthcare. By making large, diverse datasets publicly available, researchers and developers can create more robust, equitable, and generalizable AI models. The paper discusses how open data can enhance research collaboration, accelerate innovation, improve patient well-being, and promote treatment equity by reducing the barriers to entry for smaller institutions and researchers in lower-resource settings. Using the healthcare system in Andalusia, Spain, as a case study, it illustrates the potential benefits and challenges of implementing open data policies to foster a more inclusive healthcare AI ecosystem.

title: Exploring the rise and diversity of health and societal issues that use a public health approach
summarized_content: This scoping review investigates the expanding application of the term "public health approach" to a wide range of health and societal issues in literature published since 2010. The study identified 28 distinct categories of issues where this approach is advocated, including violence, substance abuse, and obesity. However, the analysis found that the term is often used without a clear, consistent definition, and its operationalization varies extensively across different fields. The authors conclude that while the adoption of a public health framework is growing, there is a need for greater clarity and consensus on its core principles and practical implementation to ensure its effectiveness.

title: Social science to accelerate coastal adaptation to sea-level rise
summarized_content: This scoping review examines the contributions of various social science disciplines to the challenge of coastal adaptation to sea-level rise. The research shows that fields such as Political Science, Economics, Sociology, and Geography are already actively supporting adaptation strategies by analyzing governance structures, economic impacts, and social vulnerability. However, the review also highlights that other social science fields, such as psychology and anthropology, are currently less developed in this context. The paper argues for a more integrated and comprehensive social science perspective to accelerate the development and implementation of effective and equitable coastal adaptation measures.

title: A Smol Perspective: Internet Sociolinguistics and the Border Between Written and Spoken Word
summarized_content: This paper explores how internet-based communication challenges the traditional linguistic distinction between written and spoken language. Through an analysis of internet sociolinguistics, it demonstrates that online interactions often exhibit features of both modalities, creating a hybrid form of communication. The use of informal language, emoticons, memes, and phonetic spellings (e.g., 'smol') in text-based media introduces elements of tone, prosody, and immediacy typically associated with speech. The author argues that the line between writing and speaking is becoming increasingly blurred, necessitating a more nuanced understanding of language use in the digital age.

title: The Value of the Humanities: Understanding the Career Destinations of Oxford Humanities Graduates
summarized_content: This report presents a detailed analysis of the career outcomes for over 9,000 humanities graduates from the University of Oxford. The study aims to quantify and articulate the value of a humanities education in the modern workforce. The findings confirm that skills cultivated through humanities studies—such as critical thinking, complex communication, and cultural understanding—are highly transferable and valued across a wide range of sectors, including business, law, government, and the creative industries. The report concludes that a humanities degree not only prepares graduates for successful careers but also equips them to make significant contributions to their workplaces and the wider world.

title: On the Reliability of Deep Neural Networks
summarized_content: This paper critically examines the reliability of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) from a fundamental epistemological perspective. It argues against the notion of DNNs as theory-free, data-driven models, emphasizing the crucial and often implicit role of model assumptions. The author contends that the high epistemic complexity and black-box nature of many DNN models make it difficult to rigorously assess their reliability and understand their failure modes. The paper calls for greater transparency and a more critical approach to evaluating DNNs, suggesting that their reliability cannot be guaranteed without a deeper understanding of the assumptions embedded within their architecture and training processes.

title: Open Access for Open Science
summarized_content: This editorial announces a significant step towards a full Open Science model at EMBO Press. Effective from 2024, The EMBO Journal and EMBO Reports will transition to become fully Open Access journals. They join other EMBO publications like EMBO Molecular Medicine and Molecular Systems Biology in this model. The move completes the transition of EMBO Press's entire journal portfolio to Open Access, reflecting a commitment to the principles of open science, which advocate for the free and unrestricted dissemination of curated, high-quality scientific research to the global community.

title: 2023 at PLOS Biology
summarized_content: This editorial by the staff of PLOS Biology provides a retrospective on the significant scientific advances published in the journal during 2023. It highlights a selection of impactful research articles that span the broad scope of the life sciences covered by the journal. The piece serves as a year-in-review, celebrating the contributions of its authors to biological research and reaffirming the journal's commitment to publishing high-quality, open-access science.

title: A Brief History of Artificial Intelligence
summarized_content: This paper provides a historical overview of the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI), tracing its origins and development. It highlights the fundamental schism that has defined AI research from its inception: the division between symbolic AI and neural networks. Symbolic AI, or 'Good Old-Fashioned AI' (GOFAI), operates on the principle that intelligence can be achieved by manipulating symbols according to formal rules. In contrast, the connectionist approach, embodied by neural networks, posits that intelligence emerges from the interconnected processing of simple units. The paper follows the trajectory of these two distinct research streams, noting their periods of dominance and decline.

title: Law and Macroeconomics: The Zero Lower Bound Challenge
summarized_content: This article argues that the legal framework needs to adapt to different macroeconomic conditions, particularly the challenge posed by the 'zero lower bound' (ZLB) on interest rates. The author posits that the economy operates under two distinct regimes. In ordinary times, output is determined by supply capacity. However, when short-term interest rates hit zero, the economy shifts to a state where aggregate demand becomes the primary determinant of output. This shift has profound implications for law and policy, suggesting that legal rules and government interventions that are optimal in normal times may be ineffective or even counterproductive at the ZLB.

title: Whatever Happened to Law and Economics?
summarized_content: This 2005 article reflects on the evolution of the law and economics movement. It claims that the field, once a distinct and often-critiqued intellectual structure dominated by the 'Chicago School,' has become so pervasive and diversified that it is no longer a single, monolithic target for critique. The author notes that in previous decades, the Chicago School's approach had distinctive characteristics centered on efficiency and rational choice. However, by the time of writing, this specific edifice shares the intellectual landscape with numerous other variants of law and economics, indicating the movement's maturation and integration into mainstream legal thought.

title: Large Language Models can accomplish Business Process Management Tasks
summarized_content: This paper explores the application of Large Language Models (LLMs) to tasks within the field of Business Process Management (BPM). BPM aims to improve organizational efficiency by analyzing and managing business processes, which often involves extracting information from unstructured textual documents like emails, reports, and customer feedback. The authors demonstrate that LLMs can effectively accomplish various text-related BPM tasks, such as process discovery from text, compliance checking, and generating process models from natural language descriptions. The research suggests that LLMs can serve as powerful tools to automate and enhance key aspects of the BPM lifecycle.

title: Natural Language Processing for Requirements Formalization
summarized_content: This work provides a guide to using Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques for the semi-automated formalization of software and system requirements. It addresses the common challenge in software engineering where requirements are initially captured in ambiguous natural language. The paper presents and discusses state-of-the-art NLP methodologies that can be used to parse these natural language requirements, identify key entities and relationships, and translate them into a more structured, formal representation. The goal is to provide readers with a framework of rules and methods to build a tailored pipeline for their specific use case, thereby reducing ambiguity and improving the quality of the requirements engineering process.

title: STEPS: A Structure-aware Self-supervised Learning Framework for Protein Representation
summarized_content: This paper introduces STEPS (STrucure-awarE Protein Self-supervised Learning), a novel method for learning protein representations. The framework is designed to explicitly incorporate protein structural information into the learned embeddings, addressing a limitation of models that rely solely on sequence data. STEPS leverages existing protein language models and combines them with structural data in a self-supervised learning context. By doing so, it aims to generate richer and more informative representations that capture both the sequence and the three-dimensional structure of proteins, which is crucial for tasks like function prediction and drug discovery.

title: Advancing inclusive research calculator for oncology disease areas
summarized_content: This paper introduces the Advancing Inclusive Research (AIR) Calculator, a tool designed to help researchers and clinical trial sponsors set meaningful diversity and inclusion targets for oncology studies. Recognizing the persistent underrepresentation of certain demographic groups in cancer research, the AIR Calculator provides a data-driven resource to support the development of diversity action plans. By offering summary tables and a data query bank, the tool aims to facilitate the establishment of evidence-based enrollment standards, ultimately promoting more equitable representation in clinical trials and ensuring that research findings are generalizable to all patient populations.

title: State of open science in cancer research
summarized_content: This study assesses the adoption of Open Science practices within the field of cancer research over the decade from 2011 to 2021. The analysis focuses on two key aspects of openness: the public accessibility of scientific publications (Open Access) and the dissemination of raw research data. By examining trends over this period, the paper provides a quantitative snapshot of how openly cancer research findings and data are being shared with the scientific community and the public. The study aims to identify progress and remaining barriers to achieving a more open and collaborative research ecosystem in oncology.

title: Enhancing Information Architecture with Machine Learning for Digital Media Platforms
summarized_content: This research thesis explores how machine learning (ML) technologies can be used to enhance the information architecture (IA) of digital multimedia platforms to improve user experience. The paper investigates methods for applying ML to tasks such as content categorization, personalized navigation, and dynamic content organization. As a practical demonstration of these concepts, the author proposes a novel information architecture model that integrates machine learning inputs to create a more adaptive, intuitive, and user-centric experience on media platforms.

title: A review of machine learning and deep learning applications in wave energy forecasting
summarized_content: This review paper provides a systematic classification and discussion of machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) algorithms applied to the field of wave energy forecasting. Accurate prediction of wave conditions is critical for the efficient operation of Wave Energy Converters (WECs). The paper surveys a range of ML and DL techniques, from traditional models to advanced neural networks, and analyzes their key characteristics and performance in predicting wave height, period, and energy flux. It also covers the use of these algorithms for optimizing the configuration and control of WECs to maximize energy capture.

title: Euler Characteristics and Homotopy Types of Definable Sublevel Sets
summarized_content: This mathematical paper studies the topological properties of sublevel sets of definable functions on definable sets, a concept from model theory. Using the framework of o-minimal structures, the authors investigate how the topology of these sets changes as the level varies. The main result of the paper is a proof that the Euler characteristic of the sublevel set, a key topological invariant, is a right-continuous function of the level. This work contributes to the understanding of the geometric and topological structure of sets defined in o-minimal theories, which have applications in areas like real algebraic geometry and data analysis.

title: The Type 2 Diabetes Knowledge Portal
summarized_content: This paper describes the Type 2 Diabetes Knowledge Portal (T2DKP), a publicly accessible online resource for researchers. The T2DKP integrates a comprehensive collection of genetic datasets and genomic annotations related to type 2 diabetes (T2D) and associated metabolic traits. The authors evaluate the comprehensiveness of the portal's data and provide a guide on how researchers can utilize its suite of tools for data exploration, visualization, and analysis. The portal is designed to facilitate the generation of new hypotheses and accelerate research into the genetic underpinnings of T2D.

title: Identification and analysis of individuals who deviate from their genetically-predicted phenotype
summarized_content: This study uses genome-wide imputed genetic data from the UK Biobank to identify individuals whose actual phenotypes deviate significantly from what would be predicted by their genetic makeup. The research focuses on two well-measured traits: standing height and LDL cholesterol levels. By developing polygenic risk scores for 158,951 unrelated individuals, the authors classify them as either concordant (phenotype matches prediction) or deviating. The analysis of these deviating individuals aims to uncover non-genetic factors or rare genetic variants that contribute to complex traits, providing insights into the limits of genetic prediction.

title: How Engineers perform Data Science Work: Designing Hybrid Roles
summarized_content: This study investigates how engineers at an international automotive supplier perform data science work, leading to the emergence of new hybrid roles. Through the analysis of three case studies involving 30 engineers, the research shows how traditional engineering roles are evolving to incorporate data science skills and responsibilities. The paper derives a model for this hybrid data science work, which effectively combines two distinct perspectives: the domain expertise and problem-solving approach of engineering with the statistical and computational methods of data science. The findings offer insights for organizations on how to design and support these critical hybrid roles.

title: The 2023 IEEE Low-Power Computer Vision Challenge
summarized_content: This article provides an overview of the 2023 IEEE Low-Power Computer Vision Challenge (LPCVC). The challenge focuses on developing computationally efficient computer vision models that can run on resource-constrained devices. The specific task for the 2023 competition was the semantic segmentation of images captured by Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) in post-disaster scenarios. The paper describes the dataset, the evaluation metrics (which balance accuracy and computational cost), and summarizes the approaches taken by the participating teams, highlighting innovations in designing lightweight and efficient neural network architectures for edge computing applications.

title: Computation-efficient Deep Learning for Computer Vision: A Survey
summarized_content: This review offers a comprehensive analysis of techniques for creating computationally efficient deep learning models, with a specific focus on computer vision applications. The survey is structured into four key areas of research: 1) the design of lightweight backbone models (e.g., MobileNets, ShuffleNets); 2) the development of specialized, efficient network architectures; 3) model compression techniques such as pruning, quantization, and knowledge distillation; and 4) strategies for efficient hardware deployment. The paper provides a systematic overview of the state-of-the-art methods that enable the deployment of powerful deep learning models on devices with limited computational resources.

title: Foundation Models in Robotics: Applications, Challenges, and the Future
summarized_content: This paper surveys the application of pre-trained foundation models in the field of robotics. It contrasts this new paradigm with traditional deep learning approaches in robotics, which typically involve training specialized models on small, task-specific datasets, limiting their adaptability and generalization. Foundation models, pre-trained on vast, internet-scale data, exhibit superior generalization capabilities. The survey reviews how these models are being adapted for various robotics tasks, including perception, planning, and control, and discusses the key challenges and future directions for leveraging large-scale pre-training to create more capable and versatile robots.

title: Large Language Models for Robotics: A Survey
summarized_content: This comprehensive review summarizes the diverse applications of Large Language Models (LLMs) in robotics. The paper delves into the impact and contributions of LLMs across several key areas of robotics, including robot control, perception, high-level decision-making, and path planning. It explores how the natural language understanding and reasoning capabilities of LLMs are being used to create more intuitive human-robot interfaces, enable robots to follow complex instructions, and perform long-horizon task planning. The survey provides a structured overview of the current state of the art and highlights the transformative potential of LLMs in this domain.

title: Disentangling Hype from Practicality: On Realistically Achieving Quantum Advantage
summarized_content: This paper offers a critical perspective on the field of quantum computing, aiming to separate realistic prospects from the growing hype. The authors question which applications are most promising for achieving a true 'quantum advantage' over classical computers in the near term. They argue that the most viable applications will likely be those that involve 'small data' problems and quantum algorithms that offer super-quadratic speedups. The paper provides a sober assessment of the challenges facing the development of fault-tolerant quantum computers and suggests a more focused research agenda centered on applications where quantum mechanics offers a fundamental, rather than merely incremental, advantage.

title: Extra-tensor-induced origin for the PTA signal
summarized_content: This paper presents a novel theoretical interpretation for the isotropic stochastic gravitational wave (GW) background signal recently detected by pulsar timing array (PTA) collaborations. While the leading hypothesis is that the signal originates from the merger of supermassive black holes, the authors propose an alternative source. They argue that the observed GW background could have originated from an extra spectator tensor field present in the early universe. The paper develops the cosmological model for this mechanism and shows that it can produce a GW signal consistent with the PTA observations.

title: The role of mass and environment in the build up of the quenched galaxy population
summarized_content: This study investigates how the probability of a galaxy being 'quenched' (i.e., having ceased star formation) depends on both its mass and its local environment. Using data from the UKIDSS Ultra-Deep Survey, the research is the first to examine this relationship over a wide redshift range, from z ~ 0.5 to z ~ 3. The findings show an excess of quenched galaxies in dense environments (like galaxy clusters) out to a redshift of at least z ~ 2. This provides strong evidence that environmental factors play a significant role in shutting down star formation in galaxies, even in the early universe.

title: High-Dimensional Statistics
summarized_content: These are lecture notes for course 18.657, High-Dimensional Statistics, at MIT. The notes provide an introduction to the field of high-dimensional statistical inference, which has developed rapidly in response to modern datasets where the number of features or variables ($p$) often far exceeds the number of observations ($n$). The material covers key concepts and methods for dealing with this '$p >> n$' problem, including regularization techniques like LASSO, random matrix theory, and methods for sparse signal recovery. The notes are intended for graduate students in statistics, machine learning, and related fields.

title: Trieste: Efficiently Exploring The Depths of Black-box Functions with TensorFlow
summarized_content: This paper introduces Trieste, an open-source Python package for Bayesian optimization and active learning. The library is built on top of TensorFlow, allowing it to benefit from the scalability, automatic differentiation, and GPU acceleration capabilities of the TensorFlow ecosystem. Trieste is designed to be a flexible and modular toolbox for sequential decision-making problems, where the goal is to efficiently optimize a black-box function. It enables users to easily plug and play various TensorFlow-based probabilistic models (like Gaussian Processes) and acquisition functions within the Bayesian optimization loop.

title: Quantum Cryptography in Algorithmica
summarized_content: This theoretical computer science paper explores the relationship between classical and quantum cryptography in a black-box setting. The authors construct a classical oracle relative to which P = NP (meaning many hard classical problems are easy), yet single-copy secure pseudorandom quantum states still exist. This result demonstrates a separation between the requirements for classical and quantum cryptography. It shows that even in a world where one-way functions (the foundation of most classical cryptography) do not exist, it is still possible to have secure quantum cryptography based on pseudorandom quantum states.

title: A Comprehensive Survey on the Implementations, Attacks, and Countermeasures of the Current NIST Lightweight Cryptography Standard
summarized_content: This paper presents the first comprehensive survey of ASCON, the cryptographic algorithm suite selected as the new standard for lightweight cryptography by NIST in 2023. Lightweight cryptography is essential for securing resource-constrained devices like RFID tags, IoT sensors, and embedded systems. The survey systematically reviews the existing literature on ASCON, covering its various hardware and software implementations, known cryptanalytic attacks (such as side-channel and fault attacks), and the corresponding countermeasures designed to protect implementations against these threats.

title: How much can ChatGPT really help Computational Biologists in Programming?
summarized_content: This paper examines the potential benefits and drawbacks of using ChatGPT for programming tasks in the field of computational biology. Through a series of illustrative examples, the authors explore various use cases, including code generation, code review, debugging, converting code between languages (e.g., Python to R), refactoring, and creating bioinformatics pipelines. The analysis highlights both the positive aspects, such as accelerating development and assisting with boilerplate code, and the negative aspects, such as the risk of generating incorrect or inefficient code and the need for careful expert validation.

title: Recent Breakthrough in AI-Driven Materials Science
summarized_content: This paper highlights two major breakthroughs in AI-driven materials science that occurred in late 2023. First, it discusses DeepMind's GNoME (Graph Networks for Materials Exploration), a powerful AI model that was used to discover over 381,000 new, stable crystalline materials, vastly expanding the known landscape of materials. Second, it covers Microsoft's release of MatterGen, a generative AI model capable of designing novel material structures based on desired target properties. These developments signal a new era in materials discovery, where AI can rapidly predict and generate new materials with potentially revolutionary applications.

title: Towards Foundation Models for Materials Science: The Open MatSci ML Toolkit
summarized_content: This manuscript details the development of the Open MatSci ML Toolkit, a framework designed to facilitate research into foundation models for materials science. The paper reviews recent progress in creating this open-source toolkit and describes a series of experiments that lay the groundwork for building large, pre-trained models for materials property prediction and discovery. The toolkit aims to provide the community with the necessary tools and benchmarks to accelerate the development and application of foundation models in this critical scientific domain.

title: Information-Theoretic Foundations for Machine Learning
summarized_content: This paper proposes a new theoretical framework for analyzing machine learning, rooted in the principles of Bayesian statistics and Shannon's information theory. The authors aim to create a general framework that can unify the analysis of many different phenomena in machine learning, such as generalization, representation learning, and active learning. The framework characterizes the performance of an optimal Bayesian learner, providing a principled, information-theoretic lens through which to understand the fundamental trade-offs in learning from data.

title: Culturally Aware and Adapted NLP: A Taxonomy and a Survey of the State of the Art
summarized_content: This paper addresses the critical need for culturally aware and adapted Natural Language Processing (NLP) systems. Drawing on research from NLP, linguistics, and social sciences, the authors propose a fine-grained taxonomy of cultural elements (e.g., social norms, values, communication styles) that influence language. This taxonomy provides a systematic framework for analyzing and understanding progress in the field. The paper then presents a comprehensive survey of the state of the art, reviewing existing methods and datasets for building NLP models that are sensitive to cultural context, with the goal of making NLP technology more equitable and effective across diverse populations.
