title: Peer reviewers from low- and middle-income countries for open access journals in oncology
summarized_content: This paper addresses the challenges faced by cancer researchers from low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) in publishing their work, particularly in open access journals where high article publishing charges (APCs) can be a significant barrier. The authors argue that a lack of representation from LMICs extends to the peer review process as well. They advocate for a concerted effort by journals to actively engage and include peer reviewers from LMICs, which would not only increase diversity and inclusivity in the scholarly publishing ecosystem but also bring valuable local context and perspectives to the evaluation of research.

title: From data strategy to implementation to advance cancer research and cancer care
summarized_content: This paper outlines the importance of a comprehensive data strategy within a cancer center to improve both research and patient care. It discusses the entire data lifecycle, from systematic data collection and warehousing to advanced analysis and secure sharing. The authors highlight the use of modern techniques, such as Natural Language Processing (NLP), to extract structured information from unstructured clinical notes. An effective data strategy is presented as essential for evaluating clinical practices, understanding disease progression, and ultimately developing more effective treatments for cancer.

title: Cardiology researchers' practices and perceived barriers to open science: an international survey
summarized_content: This study reports the findings of an international survey of researchers who publish in cardiovascular journals, examining their perceptions, practices, and barriers related to open science. The survey found that while many researchers are supportive of open science principles, practical barriers often hinder adoption. Among the various potential incentives for adopting open science practices, such as data sharing and open access publishing, the availability of funding to cover associated costs was identified as the most critical and essential factor. The results highlight the need for funders and institutions to provide tangible support to encourage the transition to more open research practices in cardiology.

title: Role of open access echocardiography in detection of cardiac structural and functional abnormalities
summarized_content: This study evaluates the effectiveness of an open access echocardiography service, where general practitioners (GPs) can directly refer patients for cardiac imaging. The research aimed to determine the prevalence of significant structural heart disease in patients referred through this service. The findings indicate that major structural and functional cardiac abnormalities are common among late middle-aged patients in this cohort. The study concludes that open access echocardiography is a valuable diagnostic tool in primary care, enabling the early detection of important cardiac conditions.

title: Imaging Neuroscience opening editorial
summarized_content: This editorial marks the launch of Imaging Neuroscience, a new non-profit, open access journal. The journal was founded by the former editorial board of the established journal NeuroImage. The authors explain that this move was a direct response to what they deemed to be unethical and unsustainable publication fees charged by the publisher of NeuroImage. The new journal is committed to fair, transparent, and community-driven scholarly publishing, aiming to provide a high-quality, affordable venue for the dissemination of research in the field of neuroimaging.

title: Open access repository-scale propagated nearest neighbor suspect spectral library for untargeted metabolomics
summarized_content: This paper addresses a key bottleneck in untargeted mass spectrometry-based metabolomics: the identification of unknown small molecules. The authors present a novel computational tool, a 'nearest neighbor suspect spectral library,' to significantly expand metabolite annotation capabilities. By propagating information from existing experimental spectral libraries to structurally similar 'suspect' molecules, this open access resource allows researchers to identify a much broader range of metabolites in their samples. This work aims to accelerate the study of the role of small molecules in complex biological systems.

title: Aerobiology-A New Open Access Journal
summarized_content: This editorial announces the launch of a new open access journal titled 'Aerobiology'. The journal aims to provide a dedicated, peer-reviewed platform for research on the airborne dispersal of biological particles. This interdisciplinary field covers topics such as pollen, fungal spores, bacteria, viruses, and other microorganisms transported through the atmosphere, and their impact on human health, agriculture, and the environment. The editorial outlines the scope of the new journal and invites contributions from the scientific community.

title: JASPAR 2024: 20th anniversary of the open-access database of transcription factor binding profiles
summarized_content: This paper presents the 10th major release of the JASPAR database, a widely used open-access resource for transcription factor (TF) binding profiles, coinciding with the database's 20th anniversary. JASPAR contains curated, non-redundant sets of profiles, typically represented as position frequency matrices, that model the DNA-binding specificity of TFs. This latest release features a significant expansion of the core collection, with 329 new profiles added, representing a 20% increase from the previous version. The paper details the updates and new features, reaffirming JASPAR's role as a fundamental tool in genomics and regulatory biology.

title: Development of an open access, virtual bioinformatics lab for students in medical laboratory sciences
summarized_content: This paper describes the development and assessment of a virtual laboratory learning unit designed to introduce basic bioinformatics concepts and tools to students in medical laboratory sciences (MLS). Recognizing the increasing importance of bioinformatics in clinical diagnostics, the authors created an accessible, online module to provide hands-on experience with common bioinformatics databases and software. The study found the unit to be a promising educational tool for MLS students. To promote wider adoption, the entire learning unit has been made available as an open educational resource.

title: GetGenome: Overcoming inequalities in access to genomics technology
summarized_content: This article highlights the persistent global inequalities in access to genomics technology, which has become an integral part of modern life science research. It introduces GetGenome, a non-profit organization founded to address this disparity. GetGenome's mission is to provide researchers, particularly in low- and middle-income countries, with equitable access to genomics technology, including sequencing services and essential training. By building local capacity and fostering international collaboration, the organization aims to overcome the technological and financial barriers that prevent many scientists from participating in the genomics revolution.

title: Symbiotic revolutions at the interface of genomics and microbiology
summarized_content: This article reflects on the concept of symbiosis in biology, noting its long and often contentious history. The author argues that the advent of new genomic technologies and research paradigms is fundamentally reshaping our understanding of symbiotic relationships. These powerful new tools are fueling a shift in some of the central tenets of the field. The paper calls for scientists to be humble and open-minded, allowing the wealth of new genomic and microbiological data to guide our theories, even if it means revising long-held ideas about how organisms interact and evolve.

title: A novel open-access artificial-intelligence-driven platform for CNS drug discovery utilizing adult zebrafish
summarized_content: This paper presents a novel, open-access platform that uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) to accelerate drug discovery for Central Nervous System (CNS) disorders. The platform analyzes the behavioral tracks of adult zebrafish, a common model organism in neuropharmacology. The researchers trained an AI system to automatically recognize and classify distinct behavioral patterns in zebrafish following treatment with various psychoactive drugs. By providing this platform as an open-access tool, the authors aim to create a high-throughput screening system that can efficiently identify new compounds with potential therapeutic effects on the CNS.

title: Open Targets Platform: facilitating therapeutic hypotheses building in drug discovery
summarized_content: This paper describes recent updates to the Open Targets Platform, a pre-competitive, open-source knowledge base designed to support systematic drug target identification and prioritization. The platform integrates a vast amount of evidence from genetics, genomics, and chemical biology to link potential drug targets to diseases. The authors detail recent improvements, including a revamped target-disease associations page and a new Target Prioritisation view, which are designed to make it easier for researchers to build and evaluate therapeutic hypotheses in the early stages of drug discovery.

title: Science in the age of AI
summarized_content: This report from The Royal Society explores the transformative impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies on scientific research. Based on the experiences of over 100 scientists, the report examines how AI is changing research methodologies, data analysis, and the very nature of scientific inquiry. It delves into the implications of AI for research integrity, the skills required by future scientists, and emerging ethical considerations. The report provides a series of recommendations, emphasizing the importance of leveraging open science principles to ensure that AI-driven contributions to science are reliable, transparent, and beneficial.

title: R&D Publications Output: U.S. Trends and International Comparisons
summarized_content: This report from the National Science Board presents a comprehensive analysis of global research publication output. It provides data on publication trends by country, region, and scientific field, highlighting a continued increase in worldwide research activity. A key finding is the dramatic growth in open access (OA) publishing; in 2022, nearly 1.6 million articles were published as OA, surpassing the 1.5 million published in closed-access journals. The report underscores the increasingly international and interconnected nature of the research ecosystem and the significant shift towards open models of dissemination.

title: Old Moats for New Models: Openness, Control, and Competition in Generative AI
summarized_content: This paper analyzes the competitive landscape of generative AI. The authors argue that despite the transformative potential of AI foundation models, the market is likely to become highly concentrated. They contend that incumbent technology firms will leverage their tight control over complementary assets—such as cloud computing infrastructure, proprietary data, and distribution channels—to build 'moats' around the new AI models. This control will likely stifle broader innovation and lead to a market structure where a few large firms capture most of the value, rather than fostering a vibrant and competitive ecosystem.

title: 2023 State of Computer Science Education
summarized_content: This report from Code.org provides a national and state-level update on K-12 computer science (CS) education in the United States. It highlights significant progress in policy adoption and student access. A key finding for 2023 is the largest single-year increase since 2018 in the percentage of high schools offering a foundational CS course. The report also discusses the growing importance of incorporating Artificial Intelligence (AI) into the CS curriculum and provides data on participation rates, emphasizing the ongoing need to broaden access and ensure equity in CS education for all students.

title: 2024: The quest continues
summarized_content: This editorial from the journal Open Biology outlines its ongoing efforts to improve the scholarly publishing experience for authors and reviewers. The journal is implementing several initiatives to make the process less frustrating and more constructive. These include joining the Review Commons platform to streamline peer review across multiple journals, introducing a system to reward reviewers for their contributions, and launching a new seminar series. The editorial also announces an upcoming special issue focused on the field of Evolutionary Cell Biology.

title: Biology Open 2024 – a year in review
summarized_content: This editorial reviews the performance and progress of the journal Biology Open during the year 2024. The primary focus is on initiatives aimed at improving the author experience through a commitment to rapid and transparent peer review. The piece presents key publication metrics for 2024, noting an overall acceptance rate of approximately 30%. It also highlights a significant improvement in efficiency, with a notable drop in the median time to an editorial rejection decision, reflecting the journal's efforts to provide authors with faster feedback.

title: Economic Well-Being of U.S. Households in 2023
summarized_content: This report from the Federal Reserve Board presents findings from the 2023 Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking (SHED). The survey indicates that the overall financial well-being of U.S. households was nearly unchanged from 2022, but remained below the high point reached in 2021. A significant portion of adults continued to report financial challenges stemming from higher prices and inflation. The report provides a detailed snapshot of how households were faring in terms of their ability to handle expenses, save for retirement, and manage debt.

title: World Economic Situation and Prospects 2024
summarized_content: This United Nations report forecasts a challenging year for the global economy in 2024. It projects continued sluggish growth, weak global trade and investment, and persistent inflation. The report expresses particular concern for developing countries, many of which are facing a spiraling debt crisis that hinders their ability to invest in sustainable development. The authors call for large-scale, coordinated investments to stimulate growth, drive climate action, and accelerate progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals.

title: How Does Data Access Shape Science? The Impact of Federal Statistical Research Data Centers on Economics Research
summarized_content: This paper investigates the impact of providing researchers with access to confidential microdata from the U.S. Census Bureau through the network of Federal Statistical Research Data Centers (FSRDCs). The study provides empirical evidence on how this access shapes the quantity, quality, and policy relevance of economic research. By addressing the long-standing debate between broadening data access for research and protecting individual privacy, the findings demonstrate the significant benefits of providing controlled access to confidential data, leading to more impactful and empirically grounded economic analysis.

title: Open access and open science: some implications for the agricultural economics profession
summarized_content: This paper serves as an introduction to a special issue of the journal Q Open focused on the implications of open access and open science for the agricultural economics profession. The authors discuss several emerging issues that applied economists must navigate in the changing scholarly landscape. These include the rise of transformative agreements, funder mandates like Plan S, the proliferation of hybrid publishing models, and the financial and operational challenges that academic societies face as they transition away from traditional subscription-based models.

title: PRESIDING OVER A LEGAL DESERT: THE DISAPPEARANCE OF THE RURAL ATTORNEY
summarized_content: This article examines the growing crisis of 'legal deserts'—areas, particularly in rural America, with a severe shortage of practicing attorneys. Using rural New Mexico as a detailed case study, the author explores the profound effects, challenges, and inequalities that arise from this lack of legal representation, both inside and outside the courtroom. The paper highlights how the disappearance of the rural attorney undermines access to justice, impacts local economies, and creates significant burdens on the legal system and residents in these underserved communities.

title: Generative AI and Legal Aid: Results from a Field Study and 100 Use Cases to Bridge the Access to Justice Gap
summarized_content: This paper presents the findings from the first field study of legal aid lawyers using generative AI to help address the access to justice gap. The study found that generative AI can be a powerful tool for increasing efficiency, with 90% of pilot participants reporting productivity gains. The paper discusses how legal aid professionals managed the risks associated with the technology, such as potential inaccuracies, by focusing on lower-risk applications like drafting documents, summarizing case law, and brainstorming legal arguments. It also catalogs 100 specific use cases for generative AI in the legal aid context.

title: The Adolescent Mental Health Crisis: A Case Study in Family Court Planning
summarized_content: This article addresses the escalating adolescent mental health crisis through the lens of family court planning, specifically in cases involving parental separation and divorce. The author argues that traditional legal processes are often ill-equipped to handle the complex mental health needs of adolescents. The paper emphasizes the necessity of developing comprehensive planning processes that integrate Family Dispute Resolution (FDR) as a central strategy. This approach aims to create more supportive, less adversarial environments that prioritize the well-being of the children involved.

title: Money and the Public Debt: Treasury Market Liquidity as a Legal Phenomenon
summarized_content: This article analyzes recent episodes of severe illiquidity in the U.S. Treasury market, typically considered the world's most liquid financial market. The authors argue that the high degree of convertibility between Treasury securities and cash is not a natural market feature but a legally constructed one. It requires financial intermediaries capable of augmenting the money supply. They contend that recent changes in market structure and regulation have shifted this role to unstable 'shadow dealers,' making the system of public finance more fragile and prone to liquidity crises.

title: The Limitations of Privacy Rights
summarized_content: This paper argues that the conventional approach to privacy protection, which is centered on individual privacy rights, is fundamentally insufficient in the digital age. The author contends that this rights-based framework has several critical limitations. It places an excessive burden on individuals to manage their own data, it cannot be effectively exercised at the scale required by modern data collection, and it fails to address the structural and interrelated nature of personal data, where one person's data can reveal information about others. The paper calls for a shift towards more systemic and structural solutions for privacy governance.

title: Degrowth and the Future of Capitalism: A Critical Review of Recent Literature
summarized_content: This review essay examines six recent books that critically inquire into the nature and future of capitalism, with a particular focus on four books from the 'degrowth' movement. The essay surveys how these works conceive of capitalism and evaluates their arguments for and against systemic change, especially in the context of the escalating environmental crisis. Degrowth proponents argue that continuous economic growth is ecologically unsustainable and socially inequitable, advocating for a planned reduction of production and consumption in wealthy nations to achieve environmental stability and social justice.

title: Understanding the Attention Economy and its Negative Effects: Consumerism is Consuming Us
summarized_content: This paper explores the 'attention economy,' a system where human attention is treated as a scarce commodity to be captured and monetized. The author argues that this product of modern capitalism is consuming its participants, leading to negative psychological and social outcomes. Despite unprecedented levels of physical security and material wealth, people are increasingly bored, anxious, and miserable. The paper links this phenomenon to the pervasive invasion of smart technology into personal lives and privacy, where individuals trade their happiness and well-being for digital engagement, resulting in mental insecurity.

title: Amazon's Algorithmic Rents: The economics of information on Amazon
summarized_content: This paper argues that Amazon's business model has evolved to extract 'algorithmic rents' from the third-party merchants who sell on its platform. The authors contend that Amazon leverages its control over the platform and its vast data resources to create information asymmetries, particularly through its advertising business. This allows Amazon to charge merchants for visibility in a marketplace it controls, impairing competition and extracting value beyond what a traditional retailer could. The paper critiques the standard antitrust model for failing to adequately capture this form of platform power.

title: INVESTIGATING THE COSTS AND ECONOMIC IMPACT OF FLIGHT DELAYS IN THE AVIATION INDUSTRY AND THE POTENTIAL STRATEGIES FOR REDUCTION
summarized_content: This study provides a comprehensive investigation into the causes, consequences, and potential mitigation strategies for flight delays in the aviation industry. It examines the various factors that contribute to delays, including airline practices like overscheduling, air traffic control congestion, weather, and technical failures. The paper analyzes the significant economic impact of these delays, which result in financial losses for airlines, airports, and passengers, as well as poor customer experience. Finally, it explores a range of strategies for reducing delays, such as improved air traffic management systems, better airline scheduling, and maintaining reserve crews and aircraft.

title: AI PROPULSION OF GLOBALIZATION: The Driving Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Global Expansion
summarized_content: This senior honors thesis argues that the rapid development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a major driving force propelling the next wave of globalization. The paper examines how AI technologies are reshaping economies, governments, and societies on a global scale. It details how AI reduces barriers to international trade and communication, facilitates cross-border data flows, and automates complex tasks, thereby deepening global integration. The thesis also explores how AI challenges traditional models of the nation-state and international relations, creating a more interconnected and interdependent world.

title: ChatGPT for Higher Education and Professional Development: A Guide to Conversational AI
summarized_content: This guide provides a practical exploration of ChatGPT for use in higher education and professional development. It is written to help students, educators, and professionals effectively and ethically utilize this conversational AI tool. The text aims to enhance efficiency, learning, and societal impact by covering key topics such as debunking common myths about AI, providing step-by-step instructions for getting started, offering advanced writing and prompting tips, and detailing specific professional applications across various fields.

title: Continuous Free Cortisol Profiles in Healthy Men: Validation of Microdialysis Method
summarized_content: This study is the first to validate a rapid sampling microdialysis method for the continuous measurement of free cortisol in both the subcutaneous tissue and blood compartments of healthy male volunteers. The research demonstrates the dynamic responses of both total and free cortisol levels following pharmacological stimulation (using ACTH) and suppression (using dexamethasone). The method provides a high-resolution view of cortisol dynamics, which is crucial for understanding the regulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis and its role in stress and disease.

title: Mfold web server for nucleic acid folding and hybridization prediction
summarized_content: This 2003 paper describes the 'mfold web server,' a valuable and widely used tool in bioinformatics for predicting the secondary structure of single-stranded nucleic acids (RNA and DNA). The server provides a user-friendly web interface to a suite of software applications that calculate the minimum free energy folding of a nucleic acid sequence, predicting its most likely two-dimensional structure. The paper outlines the server's functionalities, including RNA and DNA folding and hybridization prediction, making these powerful computational tools easily accessible to the broader scientific community.

title: Where is the land of Opportunity? The Geography of Intergenerational Mobility in the United States
summarized_content: This landmark study uses administrative data for over 40 million children and their parents to map the geography of intergenerational economic mobility in the United States. The research reveals that a child's chances of moving up the income ladder vary substantially depending on where they grow up. The paper identifies several factors that are strongly correlated with areas of high upward mobility. These include less residential segregation by race and income, lower levels of income inequality, better quality K-12 schools, higher levels of social capital (e.g., community involvement), and greater family stability.

title: Trust as a Social Reality
summarized_content: This 1985 paper proposes a sociological conceptualization of trust, moving beyond purely individual or psychological definitions. Drawing from the theoretical work of Niklas Luhmann and Bernard Barber, the authors argue that trust is a fundamental social reality that underwrites social order. They posit that trust has both emotional and cognitive dimensions and functions as a deep, often unstated, assumption that makes social interaction possible. This concept is illustrated through various examples, including the social consequences of lying, patterns of family exchange, and the collective faith required for a monetary system to function.

title: Open access research outputs receive more diverse citations
summarized_content: This study provides large-scale empirical evidence that open access (OA) research outputs receive citations from a more diverse range of sources compared to paywalled articles. By analyzing a massive bibliographic dataset, the authors find a robust association between OA status and an increased diversity of citing institutions, countries, and fields of research. The effect was found to be particularly strong for articles made open access through institutional or subject repositories (Green OA). These findings suggest that OA not only increases the number of citations but also broadens the reach and impact of research across geographical and disciplinary boundaries.

title: Lean Engineering: Doing the Right Thing Right
summarized_content: This paper summarizes research findings on applying 'lean' principles, originally developed for manufacturing, to the engineering and product development process. The authors propose a three-part framework for lean engineering. The first part is 'creating the right products,' focusing on value definition and requirements. The second is ensuring 'effective lifecycle and enterprise integration,' which involves systems thinking and collaboration. The third is using 'efficient engineering processes' to execute the work. The overarching goal of this approach is to improve value, reduce waste, and increase the affordability of complex engineered systems.

title: Urban humanities as a framework for the study of public space during the pandemic
summarized_content: This article proposes that 'urban humanities' approaches offer a valuable framework for studying public space, particularly during times of crisis like the COVID-19 pandemic. The authors argue that conventional research methods were challenged by lockdowns and social distancing. They show how methods from the urban humanities—such as thick mapping, filmic sensing, and digital storytelling—provide powerful tools to capture the lived experience and changing uses of public space. The paper develops a framework that links these qualitative, practice-based methods to the theoretical production of space at multiple scales.

title: The State of the Digital Humanities: A Report and a Critique
summarized_content: This 2016 report offers a critical examination of the rapidly expanding field of digital humanities (DH). The author argues that while DH has seen significant growth in methods, projects, and institutional recognition, it has not yet developed an adequate critical awareness of its new role within the postindustrial university and society. The critique suggests that the field is not fully prepared to take up its responsibility to critically engage with the cultural, social, and political implications of digital technology, and calls for a more self-reflective and theoretically grounded approach to its practice.

title: Open access journal publication in health and medical research and open science: benefits, challenges and limitations
summarized_content: This paper provides a comprehensive overview for authors in health and medical research on the topic of open access (OA) publishing. It summarizes the main benefits of making research openly accessible, such as increased visibility and citation. It also details the different routes for achieving OA, including Gold (publishing in a fully OA journal) and Green (archiving a version in a repository). The article aims to be a practical guide, outlining the challenges and limitations associated with each route, such as article processing charges (APCs), to help researchers make informed decisions about how and where to publish their work.

title: A cross-sectional analysis of Altmetric coverage of health research from Irish research organisations (2017-2023)
summarized_content: This study analyzes the societal impact of Irish health research from 2017 to 2023 using Altmetric data, which tracks mentions in non-traditional sources like news and social media. It finds high average attention scores for Irish health research but notes that many outputs receive no attention, providing a baseline for understanding public and policy engagement.

title: Food and Inequality
summarized_content: This paper reviews how food systems contribute to social inequalities based on class, race, and geography, exploring issues like food deserts and labor exploitation. It also highlights food as a site for resistance and social change through movements like food sovereignty.

title: Rehabilitating street children: The great paradox
summarized_content: This paper discusses the paradox of rehabilitating street children through education, noting that social stigma often hinders their integration despite successful programs. It advocates for societal changes to reduce prejudice and enhance rehabilitation outcomes.

title: Evolving Publics and the Practice of Public Sociology
summarized_content: This paper examines how the fragmented nature of modern publics affects public sociology, which seeks to engage non-academic audiences. Using historical and contemporary examples, it explores strategies for sociologists to navigate diverse communities effectively.

title: The Sociological Imagination in Challenging Times
summarized_content: This essay argues that events like the COVID-19 pandemic highlight the relevance of the sociological imagination, connecting personal experiences to public issues. It reviews C. Wright Mills’ concept and offers pedagogical strategies to teach it effectively.

title: The State of Sociology: Evidence from Dissertation Abstracts
summarized_content: This study analyzes U.S. sociology dissertation abstracts (2020-2024) to reveal trends, showing a preference for qualitative methods and focus on inequality, economics, and race. It provides a quantitative snapshot of the discipline’s current state.

title: Design anthropology for ethics of care and emergence: Reflections from an energy transition project
summarized_content: This paper uses a design anthropology approach to explore ethics as relational and emergent in an energy transition project. It advocates for a collaborative design process that addresses ethical dilemmas through context-specific care and empathy.

title: Deep hanging out, mixed methods toolkit, or something else? Current ethnographic practices in US anthropology
summarized_content: This study surveys U.S. anthropologists to identify current ethnographic methods, finding a mix of traditional fieldwork and structured mixed methods. It highlights a commitment to reflexive practices addressing power imbalances in research.

title: Reviving anthropology's past: Digital archival access and ethical collaboration with Indigenous communities
summarized_content: Failed to retrieve content. The server returned a 403 Forbidden error, indicating access to the resource is denied.

title: Constructing an Ethical Discipline: A Survey of Anthropology Program Requirements and Rhetorics
summarized_content: This study surveys U.S. anthropology programs, finding that ethics is rarely a mandatory course but often offered as an elective. It suggests programs should more visibly emphasize ethics as a core component of the discipline.

title: EcoLogits: Evaluating the Environmental Impacts of Generative AI
summarized_content: EcoLogits is an open-source Python tool for estimating the environmental impact of Generative AI API requests using Life Cycle Assessment. It helps developers and researchers assess energy consumption and carbon emissions of AI applications.

title: Mid-infrared spectroscopy and machine learning for postconsumer plastics recycling
summarized_content: This study combines mid-infrared spectroscopy with machine learning to improve post-consumer plastics recycling by accurately classifying plastic types. The method enhances the efficiency and quality of recycling mixed waste streams.

title: Environmental Science – Advances: reflections and welcome to another year of the journal
summarized_content: This editorial reviews the progress of Environmental Science: Advances, highlighting its interdisciplinary scope and recent indexing in Web of Science. It reaffirms the Royal Society of Chemistry’s commitment to fully open access publishing.

title: Younger Candidates, More Voters: The Relationship Between Candidate Age and Youth Voter Turnout
summarized_content: This study finds a correlation between candidate age and youth voter turnout in U.S. elections, but notes it is confounded by election type. After controlling for this, the effect of candidate age on youth turnout is reduced.

title: Not just by means alone: why the evolution of distribution shapes matters for understanding opinion dynamics. The case of the French reaction to the war in Ukraine
summarized_content: This study uses French survey data to show that analyzing the shape of opinion distributions, not just mean shifts, reveals nuanced dynamics like polarization in response to the 2022 Ukraine invasion. It offers a richer understanding of public opinion changes.

title: Political Issues in Social Media Campaigns for National Elections: A Plea for Comparative Research
summarized_content: This editorial introduces a comparative study of social media use in election campaigns across 14 countries, highlighting varied approaches to issue-based communication. It calls for more comparative research to understand digital campaign strategies.

title: Mary Warnock and 'public philosophy'
summarized_content: This article defends Mary Warnock’s public philosophy, emphasizing her integration of emotions in ethical judgments and public-private moral distinctions. It refutes criticisms that her public work lacked philosophical rigor.

title: Interpretative Phenomenological/Phronesis Analyses: Using Hermeneutic Ubiquitous Themes (HUTs) to Position Research Participant Experiential Narratives
summarized_content: This paper introduces Hermeneutic Ubiquitous Themes (HUTs) for Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis, providing a framework to analyze experiential narratives. It draws on philosophers like Heidegger to enhance the rigor of qualitative research.

title: Translation Notes: Heidegger, Derrida, and the Chance for (a) Philosophy
summarized_content: This paper explores translation as a philosophical practice, contrasting Heidegger’s view of it as a potential failure with Derrida’s deconstructive approach. It argues that translation’s ambiguities offer new avenues for philosophical inquiry.

title: Writing in Philosophy: Pedagogy and Practice
summarized_content: This volume provides practical guidance for teaching writing in philosophy, covering argument structuring, creative assignments, and inclusive practices. It aims to enhance students’ philosophical writing skills through diverse pedagogical strategies.

title: pi-Flow: Policy-Based Few-Step Generation via Imitation Distillation

title: Identity-Link IRT for Label-Free LLM Evaluation: Preserving Additivity in TVD-MI Scores

title: Updating the Definition of Cancer
summarized_content: This article proposes a new definition of cancer: 'a disease of uncontrolled proliferation by transformed cells subject to evolution by natural selection.' It reflects modern understanding of cancer’s biological and evolutionary dynamics.

title: Revolutionizing Cancer Treatment: Recent Advances in Immunotherapy
summarized_content: This review highlights advances in cancer immunotherapy, including monoclonal antibodies, checkpoint inhibitors, and CAR-T cell therapy. It discusses how these methods leverage the immune system for durable cancer treatment outcomes.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Health Care: Applications and Legal Implications
summarized_content: This article explores AI applications in healthcare, such as diagnostics and treatment planning, and their legal implications in regulation, malpractice, intellectual property, and privacy. It highlights the need for adapted legal frameworks.

title: Artificial Intelligence and the Problem of Autonomy
summarized_content: This article examines legal challenges of autonomous AI systems, like vehicles and weapons, focusing on issues of intent, liability, and due process. It calls for adapting legal frameworks to ensure accountability.

title: Biology-informed neural networks learn nonlinear representations from omics data to improve genomic prediction and interpretability
summarized_content: Failed to retrieve content. The server returned a 404 Not Found error, indicating the resource does not exist at this URL, possibly due to a typo or relocation.

title: World Cancer Report: Cancer research for cancer prevention
summarized_content: This IARC report synthesizes cancer research to inform prevention strategies, covering causes, biological factors, and tumor behavior. It highlights interventions like lifestyle changes and screening to reduce cancer incidence.

title: IMPLEMENTING ETHICS INTO ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
summarized_content: This article advocates for integrating ethics into AI design through risk-benefit assessments and a graded governance model. It provides a framework to translate ethical principles into practical AI development and regulation.

title: Analyzing Research Trends in Computer Science
summarized_content: Failed to retrieve content. The server returned a 404 Not Found error, indicating the resource does not exist at this URL, possibly due to a typo or relocation.

title: Towards Integrating Emerging AI Applications in SE Education
summarized_content: This paper analyzes trends in AI to propose guidelines for integrating them into software engineering curricula. It aims to help educators and students adapt to evolving AI technologies in software development.

title: The Shallow and the Deep: A biased introduction to neural networks and old school machine learning
summarized_content: This book introduces classical machine learning (e.g., regression, SVMs) and neural networks, covering their mathematical foundations and practical applications. It emphasizes model evaluation and feature engineering for students.

title: Think Python: How to Think Like a Computer Scientist - 2e
summarized_content: This book teaches programming and problem-solving using Python, covering fundamentals like variables and functions, and advanced topics like data structures and object-oriented programming. It is designed for beginners to develop computational thinking.

title: Scientific Computing for Chemists with Python
summarized_content: This book teaches Python and Jupyter for scientific computing in chemistry, covering NumPy, SciPy, Pandas, and MatplRET_b. It applies these tools to problems like spectroscopic data analysis and chemical kinetics.

title: Mathematics for Elementary Teachers
summarized_content: This book covers problem-solving, number systems, arithmetic operations, and geometry for elementary teachers. It emphasizes conceptual understanding and practical applications in education.

title: Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python
summarized_content: This MIT course introduces computer science using Python, covering data types, control structures, and object-oriented programming. It equips beginners to solve real-world problems through programming.

title: A Vision of Linear Algebra
summarized_content: This MIT course by Gilbert Strang teaches linear algebra through five matrix factorizations, connecting vector spaces and transformations to applications in data science and engineering.

title: The Analytics Edge
summarized_content: This MIT course teaches data-driven decision-making using techniques like regression, clustering, and optimization. It uses case studies to apply analytics to real-world business problems.

title: First-Principles Approach for Coupled Quantum Dynamics of Electrons and Protons
summarized_content: This paper extends RT-NEO-TDDFT to periodic systems, enabling simulations of electron-proton dynamics in materials. It models processes like proton transfer critical for chemical and biological systems.

title: Accelerated Sparse Recovery via Gradient Descent with Nonlinear Conjugate Gradient Momentum
summarized_content: This paper introduces an adaptive momentum technique for gradient descent to accelerate sparse recovery in compressed sensing. It enhances convergence for minimization problems with smooth and non-smooth functions.

Title: Introduction to Philosophy
content: This open textbook from BCcampus is a collection of chapters written by various authors and edited by Christina Hendricks, designed to serve as a comprehensive introduction to the field of philosophy.[1] The text is organized thematically, covering the main branches of philosophy: metaphysics, epistemology, logic, ethics, and political philosophy.[3, 4] It aims to provide students with the concepts and skills necessary to identify and evaluate arguments effectively, covering topics from formal logic and fallacies to necessary and sufficient conditions.[5] The book presents foundational concepts such as the Socratic method and historical movements like Rationalism and Empiricism, discussing key ideas from philosophers like Plato, Descartes, and Kant.[4, 6] Reviewers praise the text for its lucid, accessible style suitable for beginners, its consistent framework, and its use of contemporary examples to keep the subject matter fresh.[4, 5] While comprehensive in its coverage of the Western analytic tradition, some reviewers note a desire for more content on topics like causality and a more neutral presentation in areas such as metaethics.[4, 5]

Title: Financial Strategy for Public Managers
content: Financial Strategy for Public Managers is an open textbook that offers a thorough, applied, and concise introduction to essential financial concepts and analytical tools for public sector managers, assuming no prior financial knowledge.[1, 7, 8] The book intentionally blurs the lines between government, non-profit, and hybrid sectors, reflecting the reality of public service delivery.[7, 9] Its content is comprehensive, covering sources of public revenue, financial accounting (including statement preparation and analysis), transaction analysis, cost analysis, and budget strategy.[7, 8] The text is praised for its modularity, allowing instructors to use specific chapters, cases, or questions to fit various courses, such as government accounting, non-profit financial management, or public budgeting.[9] Reviewers note its practical approach, linking technical skills to managerial decision-making through real-world examples and case studies, such as the 'Cascadia Hearing School' case.[7] While some reviewers find the ordering of topics unconventional (e.g., accounting before budgeting), they acknowledge that the structure is easily customizable. Minor critiques include some dated financial examples, uneven quality of screenshots in the PDF version, and the absence of an index or glossary.[7, 9]

Title: Matrix Calculus for Machine Learning and Beyond
content: This MIT OpenCourseWare (OCW) course provides a comprehensive background in matrix calculus, a critical notation for expressing and solving problems in machine learning, large-scale optimization, and other scientific fields.[1, 10] Taught by Professors Alan Edelman and Steven G. Johnson, the course extends beyond standard single-variable and multivariable calculus to cover calculus on arbitrary vector spaces.[10] It emphasizes a holistic approach, teaching students to think of matrices as complete entities rather than just arrays of scalars. Key topics include the generalization and computation of derivatives for complex matrix operations and factorizations, the concept of derivatives as linear operators (Jacobians), and the practical application of reverse-mode differentiation (backpropagation).[11, 12] The course also delves into how modern automatic differentiation (AD) techniques are implemented, contrasting them with symbolic formulas and finite differences. The curriculum covers adjoint methods, custom vector-Jacobian products, and applications in nonlinear root-finding and optimization, making it highly relevant for students and practitioners in applied mathematics, computer science, and engineering.[10, 11, 13]

Title: Psychology 2e
content: Psychology 2e is a comprehensive open textbook from OpenStax designed to meet the scope and sequence requirements for a single-semester introductory psychology course.[1] The book offers a thorough treatment of core psychological concepts, grounded in both classic studies and current, emerging research. Its content is structured to cover the scientific study of mind and behavior, beginning with the history of psychology and an overview of contemporary approaches and career paths in the field.[14] The text uses compelling case studies—such as those of musician Clive Wearing, who lost his ability to form new memories, and mathematician John Nash, who was diagnosed with schizophrenia—to introduce complex questions about how the human brain works and the connection between internal processes and external behaviors. This approach aims to engage students by illustrating psychological principles through real-world examples. The book is structured to provide a broad introduction to the various ways the field of psychology explores these fundamental questions.[14]

Title: College Algebra 2e
content: College Algebra 2e is an open-source textbook from OpenStax that provides comprehensive and accessible materials for a standard college algebra course. The book is designed to be used as a primary text and is accompanied by a range of free online resources, including a study guide, to support student learning.[1] The content covers the fundamental principles of algebra, preparing students for further study in mathematics. Its modular structure allows instructors to adapt the material to various course syllabi and teaching approaches. The textbook emphasizes clear explanations, numerous examples, and practice exercises to reinforce concepts. As part of the OpenStax library, it aims to reduce the financial burden on students while providing high-quality, peer-reviewed educational content.

Title: Principles of Accounting, Volume 1: Financial Accounting
content: Principles of Accounting, Volume 1: Financial Accounting is an open-source textbook from OpenStax that covers the fundamental concepts of financial accounting. It is designed for introductory accounting courses and provides a comprehensive overview of the subject matter.[1] Key topics include the complete accounting cycle, from recording transactions to preparing financial statements. The book also delves into the analysis of these financial statements, providing students with the tools to interpret financial data for decision-making. The text is structured to build a strong foundation in accounting principles, making it suitable for students who plan to pursue further studies in business and accounting as well as those who need a basic understanding of financial reporting for other fields. As with other OpenStax resources, it is available for free online and is designed to be a cost-effective alternative to traditional textbooks.

Title: Introduction to Sociology 3e
content: Introduction to Sociology 3e is an open textbook from OpenStax that aligns with the topics and objectives of many introductory sociology courses. The book is structured to first provide foundational sociological theories and contexts, then progress through various aspects of human society.[1] It uses relatable, everyday examples, such as the unspoken social rules and collective behaviors observed in a busy commuter train station, to illustrate complex sociological concepts.[15] The text covers the history of sociology, key theoretical perspectives, and the reasons for studying the discipline. It emphasizes that understanding sociology is not just an academic exercise but a meaningful tool for comprehending our own lives and futures, influencing everything from government policy to personal relationships. The book aims to demonstrate how sociologists study society and how their work can lead to a deeper understanding of social dynamics and structures.[15]

Title: Hybrid-Flexible Course Design
content: Hybrid-Flexible Course Design: Implementing Student-Directed Hybrid Classes, authored by Brian J. Beatty, is a comprehensive guide to the Hybrid-Flexible (HyFlex) course design model.[1, 16] This pedagogical approach combines online and in-person (classroom-based) students in a single course, giving students the choice of which mode to participate in from session to session.[17, 18] The book provides readers with strategies, methods, and real-world case stories to help them make informed decisions about implementing HyFlex in their own teaching contexts.[19] It covers the fundamental principles and values of HyFlex, such as student choice and flexibility, and details a process for designing, developing, and teaching a HyFlex course. The text also addresses implementation factors for instructors, students, and administrators, drawing on examples from various higher education institutions worldwide.[16, 17] Key topics include supporting and evaluating HyFlex programs, the costs and benefits, and navigating the technological and pedagogical requirements for successful implementation.[16, 18]

Title: Writing Instruction Tips For Automated Essay Graders
content: Writing Instruction Tips For Automated Essay Graders: How To Design an Essay for a Non-human Reader by Alise Lamoreaux is an open textbook that provides practical guidance for students and instructors on how to approach writing for Automated Essay Grading (AEG) systems.[1, 20] The book argues that as artificial intelligence becomes more prevalent in education and the workplace, understanding how to write for a non-human reader is a critical skill.[21] It offers a background on AEG systems, explaining what they can assess and what research reveals about their focus on specific linguistic features, such as word choice and lexical complexity.[20, 22] The text provides specific strategies for structuring responses, developing audience awareness, and understanding argumentative frameworks like the Toulmin Method.[20, 21] It includes practice activities to help writers learn to 'think' like a robo-grader. Reviewers have praised the book for its thorough background, clear and accessible writing style, and logical organization, though some note that its source references are somewhat dated given the rapid evolution of AI.[20]

Title: Introduction to Tourism and Hospitality in B.C. – 2nd Edition
content: This is the second edition of an open textbook from BCcampus Open Textbooks, first published in 2015. This updated version provides a timely introduction to the tourism and hospitality industry with a specific focus on British Columbia, Canada.[1] The textbook is designed for students and newcomers to the field, covering the fundamental concepts, sectors, and career pathways within the industry. A key feature of this edition is the integration of interactive H5P activities, designed to enhance student engagement and reinforce learning. The content has been refreshed to reflect current trends, challenges, and opportunities in the B.C. tourism and hospitality landscape. As an open educational resource, it aims to provide free and accessible learning materials to support education and professional development in this vital economic sector for the province.[1]

Title: Fundamentals of Materials Science
content: This MIT OpenCourseWare (OCW) course is an introductory lecture class for sophomore students in Materials Science and Engineering, focusing on the fundamentals of structure, energetics, and bonding that underpin the field.[1, 23] The course is designed to be taken alongside companion lab and mathematics courses (3.014 and 3.016) to provide a unified introduction to the subject. Key topics include an introduction to thermodynamic functions and laws governing equilibrium properties, relating macroscopic behavior to atomistic and molecular models. It explores the role of electronic bonding in determining the energy, structure, and stability of materials, using quantum mechanical descriptions. The curriculum also covers materials phenomena such as heat capacities, phase transformations, multiphase equilibria, chemical reactions, and magnetism. Additional topics include symmetry properties, the structure of complex and amorphous materials, and the use of diffraction for structure determination. The course applies these fundamental concepts to real-world materials, including engineered alloys, electronic and magnetic materials, polymers, and biomaterials.[23]

Title: Structure of Materials
content: Structure of Materials is a three-part MIT OpenCourseWare (OCW) course that explores the arrangement of internal components in a wide variety of materials with current engineering applications.[1, 24] The course posits that a material's structure determines nearly all of its properties and performance. The content is equivalent to MIT's sophomore-level materials structure curriculum. Part 1 introduces amorphous materials, focusing on glasses and polymers, including the factors influencing their structure and how scientists measure and describe them. It then transitions to crystalline materials, covering how to describe the periodic arrangement of atoms and determine crystal structure through X-ray diffraction. Parts 2 and 3 delve deeper into the structure of materials. The course is archived on the Open Learning Library, allowing users to access all materials freely, with an option to enroll to track progress.[24]

Title: Learn to Build Your Own Videogame with the Unity Game Engine
content: This MIT OpenCourseWare (OCW) resource documents a 9-day, hands-on workshop on designing, building, and publishing simple educational videogames, offered during MIT's Independent Activities Period (IAP).[1, 25] The course requires no prior experience in programming or game design, catering to both beginners and advanced students. Participants learn to use the Unity game engine, a cross-platform development tool, for videogame creation. The curriculum also covers collaborative software development using GitHub, gesture handling with the Microsoft Kinect, 3D digital object creation, and principles of videogame design and small team management. The course provides an overview of the Unity software interface to ensure all students start on an even footing before moving into guided tutorials and projects. The materials include demonstration and tutorial videos, project examples, and instructor insights, making it a comprehensive resource for anyone interested in learning the fundamentals of game development.[1, 25]

Title: Business Fundamentals
content: Business Fundamentals is an all-encompassing introductory textbook from the Open Textbook Library designed to introduce readers to the world of business.[1] It is specifically geared toward college and university students, particularly those with little to no prior experience in the subject. The book aims to provide a solid foundation in the core principles and functions of business, covering a wide range of topics essential for understanding how organizations operate. These topics likely include areas such as management, marketing, finance, accounting, and entrepreneurship, providing a holistic view of the business environment. As an open educational resource, it offers a free and accessible alternative to traditional textbooks, supporting students in their foundational business education.[1]

Title: Accounting Principles: A Business Perspective
content: Accounting Principles: A Business Perspective is an open textbook designed to teach accounting concepts from a practical, business-oriented viewpoint.[1] A key pedagogical feature of this book is its use of annual reports from real companies to illustrate accounting principles in action. This approach helps students connect theoretical concepts to their application in the business world, making the material more relevant and understandable. The textbook covers the foundational principles of accounting, likely including topics such as the accounting cycle, financial statement preparation, and analysis of financial data. By grounding the instruction in real-world examples, the book aims to provide students with a clear perspective on how accounting information is used for decision-making in a business context.[1]

Title: Population Health for Nurses
content: Population Health for Nurses is an OpenStax textbook that introduces the topic of population health and clarifies the central role nurses play in advancing it.[1] The book distinguishes population health nursing from the related fields of public and community health, explaining that while public/community health is a broad discipline focused on organized efforts and policies for societal well-being, population health nursing specifically focuses on the health status and outcomes of groups of people.[26] It introduces the Healthy People 2030 program, a U.S. government initiative that sets measurable national health objectives, and integrates its goals throughout the text. The book uses a case study approach, following a character named Alexandra Lee, to explore how population, public, and community health principles impact individual and family well-being in real-world scenarios, including addressing health disparities related to systemic racism.[26]

Title: Clinical Nursing Skills
content: Clinical Nursing Skills is an OpenStax textbook that showcases the multifaceted nature of nursing practice by providing a foundation in comprehensive, holistic patient care.[1] The book covers the core principles of nursing practice, including person-centered care, professional integrity, and the importance of lifelong learning. It emphasizes evidence-based practice and the nursing process as foundational frameworks for delivering high-quality care.[27] The text also highlights the significance of establishing therapeutic relationships, effective communication, and cultural competence as essential components of providing comprehensive care that addresses not only the physical but also the emotional, psychological, and social well-being of patients. By focusing on these principles, the book prepares aspiring nurses to act as effective advocates for their patients, ensuring patient needs and preferences are central to all care decisions.[27]

Title: Maternal Newborn Nursing
content: Maternal Newborn Nursing is an OpenStax textbook that provides comprehensive coverage of nursing care for individuals assigned female at birth (AFAB) throughout their lifespan, with a focus on the perinatal period.[1] The content ranges from contraception and preconception counseling to preventive health care, as well as care during the antepartum, intrapartum, and postpartum periods. A key theme is the role of the nurse as an advocate, particularly for marginalized populations, including persons of color and LGBTQIA+ individuals.[28] The text emphasizes providing supportive, nonjudgmental care and tailoring care plans to the individual's physical, mental, social, and cultural needs. It also addresses the nurse's role in screening for issues like intimate partner violence and postpartum depression, and in influencing health policies affecting persons AFAB. The book is designed to equip nurses with the fundamental knowledge to provide quality, safe care for the parent-newborn couplet.[28]

Title: Pharmacology for Nurses
content: Pharmacology for Nurses is an OpenStax textbook designed to provide nursing students with a fundamental understanding of the pharmacological use of drugs required for safe and effective patient care.[1] The book emphasizes the importance of comprehending both the mechanisms by which drugs affect the human body (pharmacodynamics) and how a patient's physiological factors influence drug responses (pharmacokinetics). A key feature of the text is its integration of pathophysiology; alongside discussions of each body system, it reviews the underlying disease processes and the corresponding medications used in treatment.[29] The book acknowledges the constantly evolving nature of medicine and stresses the need for nurses to engage in lifelong learning to stay current with new drugs and research. The overall goal is to equip nurses with the essential knowledge to administer medications safely and effectively across various clinical settings.[29]

Title: Astronomy 2e
content: Astronomy 2e is an OpenStax textbook that offers an engaging introduction to the study of objects beyond Earth and the processes by which they interact.[1] The book emphasizes that science is a 'progress report,' continually evolving as new discoveries are made. It traces the evolutionary processes that shape the universe, from the very small to the large scale.[30] The text aims to make astronomy accessible and exciting by highlighting fascinating cosmic phenomena, such as vast canyon systems on Mars, collapsed stars of incredible density, and the faint radio echo of the universe's creation. Beyond describing celestial objects, the book focuses on the scientific process itself—how astronomers gather information from the cosmos, particularly by decoding the 'message of starlight,' and the tools used to do so. The goal is to equip readers with a foundational understanding of both the universe and the methods of astronomical inquiry.[30]

Title: Biology for AP® Courses
content: Biology for AP® Courses is an OpenStax textbook designed to cover the scope and sequence requirements of a typical two-semester Advanced Placement® (AP®) biology course.[1] The book offers comprehensive coverage of foundational research and core biological concepts, all viewed through an evolutionary lens. It introduces the central theme of the unity and diversity of life, explaining that while the cell is the basic unit, its utilization across different organisms is hugely varied, reflecting adaptation to specific environments.[31] The text uses examples such as the co-evolution of humans and the malaria-causing organism *Plasmodium* to illustrate natural selection and the scientific process. It emphasizes how biologists use both inductive and deductive reasoning to learn about the world. The book also includes teacher support sections that provide guidance on introducing key concepts, such as geological time scales and the role of natural selection in human genetics.[31]

Title: Chemistry: Atoms First 2e
content: Chemistry: Atoms First 2e is an introductory OpenStax textbook that takes a non-traditional approach by presenting atomic and molecular structure much earlier than standard chemistry texts.[1] This 'atoms first' methodology aims to provide students with a solid foundation in the fundamental building blocks of matter before delving into more complex topics. Subsequent chapters then link back to these core concepts, helping students understand the application of quantitative principles in chemistry.[32] The book frames the study of chemistry as being integral to everyday life, using relatable examples like making coffee, using soap, and fueling a car to demonstrate that chemical substances and processes are all around us. The text covers essential principles underlying modern chemistry, including the phases and classification of matter, physical and chemical properties, and the mathematical treatment of measurements.[32]

Title: Organic Chemistry
content: This OpenStax textbook, authored by John McMurry, is renowned for being one of the most clearly written books available for a two-semester organic chemistry course.[1] It follows a functional group approach and has been updated with new scientific discoveries and applications. The book defines organic chemistry as the study of carbon compounds, explaining that carbon's unique ability to form four strong covalent bonds and create long chains and rings allows for an immense diversity of molecules, from simple methane to complex DNA.[33] The text begins by reviewing foundational concepts from general chemistry, such as atomic structure, orbitals, electron configurations, and chemical bonding theories (both valence bond and molecular orbital). It then systematically covers the hybridization of orbitals ($sp^3$, $sp^2$, and $sp$) to explain the structure of fundamental organic molecules like methane, ethane, ethylene, and acetylene, before discussing the hybridization of other key elements like nitrogen and oxygen.[33]

Title: American Government 3e
content: American Government 3e is an OpenStax textbook that provides a comprehensive introduction to the U.S. system of government, designed to foster meaningful engagement with the material.[1] The book covers foundational principles, political behavior, and the institutions of government. It frames the subject around the importance of civic engagement, tracing the historical struggles for the right to participate in government, from the American Revolution to the fights for suffrage by women, African Americans, and other groups.[34] The text explores fundamental questions about the purpose and different forms of government, and how citizens can best participate in the democratic process. It emphasizes that political engagement is crucial to ensure that the government serves the people. The book is structured to answer key questions such as 'What is government?', 'Who governs?', and 'How can citizens engage in a democracy?'.[34]

Title: Introduction to Anthropology
content: Introduction to Anthropology is a four-field open textbook from OpenStax that integrates diverse voices, engaging field activities, and meaningful themes to enrich learning about the study of humanity.[1] The book emphasizes a holistic approach, aiming to overcome bias by examining cultures as complex products of specific environmental and historical conditions. It introduces the vast scope of anthropology through diverse research examples, such as the discovery of a 9,000-year-old female hunter in Peru, a global study on smartphone use, and primate behavior observation in Uganda.[35] Key themes include Indigenous experiences and social inequality. The text teaches core anthropological methods like cross-cultural comparison and cultural relativism, and it encourages students to suspend judgment while learning to understand an 'insider’s point of view.' The goal is to provide a set of skills for keeping an open mind while exploring the full, and sometimes challenging, diversity of human practices and ideas.[35]

Title: Introduction to Political Science
content: Introduction to Political Science is an OpenStax textbook that serves as an introduction to the world of politics and the systematic study of the field.[1] The text teaches fundamental principles and core concepts to help students become better-prepared citizens and political actors. It argues that politics is ubiquitous, affecting everything from the technology we use (like smartphones) to the most intimate details of our lives.[36] The book is structured to help students understand 'who gets what, when, how, and why.' It covers the definitions of politics, public policy, and power, and distinguishes between normative (what should be) and empirical (what is) political science. The text encourages students to 'think like a political scientist' by seeking and scrutinizing evidence, thereby becoming more resilient to misinformation and better able to navigate a complex political world.[36]

Title: Contemporary Mathematics
content: Contemporary Mathematics is an OpenStax textbook that introduces concepts of modern mathematics relevant to a variety of fields.[1] The book begins with foundational topics in set theory, using the analogy of a flatware drawer to explain the concept of a set as a well-defined collection of distinct objects.[37] It then introduces Venn diagrams as a graphical method for illustrating relationships between different groups or sets. This grounding in set theory is presented as foundational to statistical studies, where sets are used to define populations of interest, such as control and treatment groups in a research study. The curriculum covers basic set concepts, subsets, the interpretation of Venn diagrams, and set operations involving two or more sets, providing a structured introduction to these essential mathematical tools.[37]

Title: University Physics Volume 1
content: University Physics Volume 1 is the first book in a three-volume set from OpenStax, designed for a two- or three-semester calculus-based physics course.[1] This volume covers mechanics, sound, oscillations, and waves. The text emphasizes the underlying unity and simplicity of the laws of physics, which describe phenomena from the atomic to the galactic scale.[38] It introduces the scope and scale of physics, the importance of units and standards, and practical skills such as unit conversion, dimensional analysis, and problem-solving techniques. The book aims to show students the relevance of physics in their daily lives and future careers, regardless of their specific goals. Key concepts covered include standards, unit conversion, dimensional analysis, significant figures, and estimation techniques.[38]

Title: University Physics Volume 2
content: University Physics Volume 2 is the second installment in a three-volume series from OpenStax, designed for calculus-based introductory physics courses.[1] This volume focuses on thermodynamics, electricity, and magnetism. The text introduces heat and temperature as core concepts in thermodynamics, explaining that the laws of thermodynamics govern energy flow throughout the universe and are fundamental to all areas of science and engineering.[39] Key topics covered in this volume include temperature and thermal equilibrium, thermometers and temperature scales, thermal expansion, heat transfer mechanisms (conduction, convection, radiation), specific heat, calorimetry, and phase changes. The book aims to demonstrate how these principles affect everything from molecular behavior to large-scale phenomena like weather and the life cycles of stars.[39]

Title: University Physics Volume 3
content: University Physics Volume 3 is the final book in a three-volume set from OpenStax for calculus-based physics courses, focusing on optics and modern physics.[1] The text begins by investigating the nature and behavior of light, framed by two fundamental questions: 'What is light?' and 'How does it behave?'. It connects these questions to Maxwell's equations, which predict electromagnetic waves, and also introduces the concept of wave-particle duality, a cornerstone of modern physics.[40] The optics section covers the propagation of light, the law of reflection, refraction, total internal reflection, dispersion, Huygens's principle, and polarization. The modern physics section delves into topics such as relativity, photons, matter waves, quantum mechanics, and nuclear physics. The book aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of light's interaction with optical devices and the foundational principles of twentieth-century physics.[1, 40]

Title: Workplace Software and Skills
content: Workplace Software and Skills is an OpenStax textbook designed to cover the fundamental computing skills needed in a modern corporate environment.[1] The book is framed around a fictional multinational corporation, WorldCorp, to provide a practical context for learning. It covers the history of computing, computer hardware, networks, the internet, cloud computing, and the Internet of Things.[41] A significant portion of the text is dedicated to hands-on training in essential business software suites, specifically Microsoft 365 (Office) and Google Workspace. It also addresses crucial topics such as online safety, security, privacy, and the ethical use of technology. The book aims to equip students and new employees with the foundational skills for tasks like formatting documents, creating spreadsheets, designing presentations, and conducting virtual meetings, which are essential regardless of employment level.[41]

Title: U.S. History
content: U.S. History is an OpenStax textbook that covers the breadth of the chronological history of the United States, providing the necessary depth to ensure the course is manageable for both instructors and students.[1] The book frames American history within the context of globalization, beginning with the European search for new trade routes to Asia that led to the encounter with the 'New World'.[42] It covers the diverse societies of the Americas, Europe on the brink of change, and West Africa, emphasizing the interconnectedness of these three worlds. The text highlights that while Europeans came to dominate the New World, their success was dependent on the roles played by African and Native peoples. The curriculum is designed to explore the experiences of a wide range of people and provides a narrative from the pre-Columbian era through major historical periods.[1, 42]

Title: World History Volume 1, to 1500
content: World History Volume 1, to 1500 is the first of a two-volume set from OpenStax that explores human history from its origins to the year 1500.[1] The book emphasizes a global perspective, the use of primary sources, and the critical concepts of causation and interpretation in history. It defines history not just as a record of events, but as a path to understanding the present and a means for self-reflection and improvement.[43] The text acknowledges that history is an ever-evolving field, with each new source uncovered providing a more precise record. The curriculum is designed to take students on a journey through the major cultures, states, and societies across the globe, focusing on cross-cultural interactions and providing a comprehensive narrative of the human tale up to the early modern period.[1, 43]

Title: World History Volume 2, from 1400
content: World History Volume 2, from 1400 is the second of a two-volume set from OpenStax that explores human history from the year 1400 to the present day.[1] The book continues the approach of its predecessor, emphasizing a global perspective, the critical use of primary sources, and an understanding of historical causation and interpretation. It frames the study of history as a vital tool for understanding ourselves and the complexities of the modern world.[44] The text posits that history is not a static chronicle but a dynamic field where new discoveries continually refine our understanding of the past. The curriculum is designed to provide a comprehensive and true reflection of the past, encouraging students to engage critically with the events, cultures, and interactions that have shaped the contemporary global landscape.[1, 44]

Title: Artificial Intelligence and Intellectual Property: An Economic Perspective
content: This WIPO Economic Research Working Paper dissects the dual role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) as both a facilitator and a disruptor of innovation and creativity.[1] The paper places the current debate on AI and intellectual property (IP) into a broader economic context, examining how AI's capabilities affect the incentive structures that underpin the IP system. It distinguishes between four types of AI inventions/creations: core AI models, AI-assisted creations, AI-based creations (where AI is part of the output), and fully AI-generated creations.[45] The authors argue that while AI can be seen as a tool enhancing human capabilities, its potential to replace human ingenuity poses fundamental questions for IP law, such as the patentability of AI-generated inventions or copyright for AI-generated novels. The paper explores the evolving landscape of AI innovation incentives and the economic ramifications of potential legal adjustments to existing IP frameworks, which were originally designed for human-centric innovation.[1, 45]

Title: Access to science and innovation in the developing world
content: This WIPO Economic Research Working Paper examines the impact of lowering barriers to online access to scientific publications on science and innovation in developing countries.[1] The study investigates the UN-led Research4Life (R4L) initiative, specifically the WHO-led Hinari subprogramme for health sciences, which provides free or low-cost journal access to institutions in developing nations.
