This includes detailed discussions of the ontological, cosmological, and teleological (design) arguments for God's existence, as well as the primary arguments against, such as the problem of evil, which questions how the existence of an all-good, all-powerful God is compatible with the suffering in the world. The book also explores the complex relationship between faith and reason, addressing questions about whether religious belief can be rational. It aims to provide students with the analytical tools to critically evaluate arguments on all sides of these issues, fostering a deeper understanding of the philosophical questions that arise from religious belief and practice.

Title: Introduction to Philosophy: Aesthetics
content: This open textbook serves as an introduction to aesthetics and the philosophy of art. The book is designed for introductory-level students and explores fundamental questions about the nature of art, beauty, and aesthetic experience. It prompts students to consider what defines something as a work of art and examines various theories that have been proposed to answer this question, such as representational, formalist, and institutional theories of art. The textbook also delves into the nature of beauty and other aesthetic qualities, questioning whether they are objective properties of things or subjective responses of the observer. It explores the nature of aesthetic experience and judgment, and the relationship between art and other domains of value, such as morality and knowledge. By examining different historical and contemporary theories of art and aesthetics, the book aims to provide students with a framework for thinking critically about the arts and the role they play in human life.

Title: Introduction to Philosophy Reader Series
content: This volume is an open educational resource designed as a collection of primary source readings for introductory philosophy courses. It serves as a companion to a standard introductory textbook or can be used as a standalone reader. The collection is curated to provide students with direct access to the foundational texts of philosophy, covering a wide range of topics and historical periods. The readings span the major branches of philosophy, including metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, and political philosophy. The anthology includes excerpts from canonical figures in the history of Western philosophy, from Plato and AristRET_ to Descartes, Hume, Kant, and more contemporary thinkers. The primary goal of this reader is to allow students to engage directly with the arguments and writing styles of influential philosophers, moving beyond secondary summaries to interpret and analyze the original works for themselves. It is designed to be a flexible resource that instructors can adapt to the specific needs of their courses.

Title: Writing a Successful Philosophy Paper
content: This open educational resource is a practical guide designed to help undergraduate students master the specific skills required to write a successful philosophy paper. The guide breaks down the writing process into manageable stages, offering clear advice and strategies for each step. It begins with the initial stages of choosing a suitable topic and developing a clear, arguable thesis statement. It then provides detailed instruction on how to structure a philosophical argument, emphasizing the importance of logical coherence, clear definitions, and the anticipation of counterarguments. The guide covers the mechanics of writing, including how to write with precision and clarity, and provides instruction on proper citation practices for philosophical sources. It aims to demystify the process of philosophical writing, which often differs significantly from writing in other disciplines, by providing students with a concrete set of tools and techniques. The ultimate goal is to empower students to move from summarizing the views of others to constructing their own well-reasoned and persuasive philosophical arguments.

Title: The Open Anthology of Earlier American Literature
content: This open anthology provides a curated selection of texts from the period of earlier American literature, designed for use in introductory undergraduate courses. The collection covers the span from the colonial period through the mid-19th century, offering a broad survey of the foundational works of the American literary tradition. A key feature of the anthology is its inclusion of works by a diverse range of authors, aiming to present a more inclusive and representative canon than some traditional anthologies. It includes texts from various genres, such as exploration narratives, Puritan sermons, captivity narratives, poetry, essays, and fiction. The anthology is designed as a flexible and accessible resource for both students and instructors, providing a cost-free alternative to commercial textbooks. It allows students to engage directly with the primary literary texts that shaped early American culture and thought, providing a foundation for understanding the subsequent development of American literature.

Title: An Introduction to Philosophy
content: This open textbook offers a broad and accessible introduction to the main areas of Western philosophy. It is specifically designed for students with no prior background in the subject, aiming to provide a clear and engaging entry point into philosophical inquiry. The textbook is structured to cover the major branches of philosophy. This includes metaphysics, which explores fundamental questions about the nature of reality; epistemology, which investigates the nature and scope of knowledge; ethics, which examines moral principles and values; and political philosophy, which considers questions of justice, rights, and the nature of the state. The book introduces students to the key questions, concepts, and historical figures associated with each of these areas. By presenting complex ideas in a straightforward manner, the textbook seeks to equip students with the foundational knowledge and analytical skills needed to think philosophically and to engage with the enduring questions that have shaped human thought.

Title: The Open Anthology of Folk and Fairy Tales
content: This open anthology presents a diverse collection of folk and fairy tales from various cultures and traditions around the world. The book is designed for use in courses on folklore, literature, or cultural studies. A key feature of the anthology is its thematic organization, which allows for comparative analysis of how different cultures have approached universal themes such as heroism, transformation, and justice through their traditional stories. The collection includes both classic, well-known tales from sources like the Brothers Grimm and Hans Christian Andersen, as well as a wide selection of lesser-known stories from different global regions. Each section is accompanied by introductory material that provides cultural and historical context for the tales. The anthology also includes discussion questions and prompts for analysis, encouraging students to think critically about the structure, symbolism, and social functions of these stories. As an open educational resource, it provides a cost-free and flexible tool for exploring the rich and varied world of folk and fairy tales.

Title: Open Music Theory, Version 2
content: This open textbook, now in its second version, provides a comprehensive introduction to the fundamentals of music theory. The book is designed to be a primary resource for undergraduate music theory courses. It covers the core topics of the discipline, beginning with the building blocks of music such as pitch, rhythm, and meter. It then progresses to more complex concepts in harmony, including scales, intervals, chords, and harmonic progressions. The textbook also covers musical form and structure, analyzing the principles that govern the organization of musical works. A key pedagogical feature of this resource is its interactivity; it includes numerous embedded exercises and musical examples that allow students to actively engage with the material. The book draws on examples from a wide range of musical styles, from classical and jazz to pop and folk, to illustrate the theoretical concepts in diverse contexts. The goal is to provide a modern, accessible, and engaging resource for learning music theory.

Title: Understanding Music: Past and Present
content: This open textbook offers a chronological survey of the history of Western music, designed for introductory music history or music appreciation courses. The book guides students through the major periods of music history, beginning with the music of the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, and progressing through the Baroque, Classical, Romantic, and 20th-century periods to the present day. For each historical period, the textbook covers the major composers, significant genres (e.g., symphony, opera, string quartet), and key stylistic developments. The text is designed to be accessible to students without a formal music background. A key feature of the book is the inclusion of listening guides for important musical works. These guides provide a minute-by-minute commentary on the piece, pointing out key musical events, formal sections, and instrumentation to help students develop their active listening skills. The goal is to provide a comprehensive historical and cultural context for understanding the evolution of Western art music.

Title: History in the Making: A History of the People of the United States of America to 1877
content: This open textbook provides a comprehensive survey of American history, covering the period from the pre-Columbian era up to the end of the Reconstruction era in 1877. The book is designed for the first half of a typical introductory U.S. history course sequence. A distinguishing feature of this textbook is its emphasis on a 'history from the bottom up' approach. While it covers the major political and economic events of the period, it places a strong focus on the experiences of ordinary people, including Native Americans, women, enslaved people, and working-class Americans. This approach aims to provide a more inclusive and multi-faceted narrative of American history. To support this pedagogical goal, the textbook integrates a wide variety of primary source documents directly into the text. These sources allow students to engage with the historical evidence firsthand and to hear the voices of people from the past. The book aims to provide a manageable yet thorough overview of early American history.

Title: World History: Cultures, States, and Societies to 1500
content: This open textbook offers a broad survey of world history from the origins of human civilization up to the year 1500. It is designed for the first part of a standard introductory world history course sequence. The textbook adopts a global perspective, covering the major cultures, states, and societies across different regions of the world, including Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Americas. Rather than presenting regional histories in isolation, the book places a strong emphasis on cross-cultural interactions, such as trade, migration, and the exchange of ideas and technologies. It aims to help students understand the interconnectedness of human societies throughout history. The textbook covers the development of major civilizations, belief systems, and political and economic structures. It is written to be accessible to introductory-level students and provides a foundational understanding of the diverse and complex history of the world before the early modern era.

Title: Exploring Public Speaking, 4th Edition
content: This open textbook, now in its fourth edition, provides a comprehensive introduction to the theory and practice of public speaking. It is designed for introductory communication courses and aims to equip students with the essential skills to become confident and effective speakers. The textbook covers the entire speech-making process in a systematic way. It begins with foundational topics such as overcoming speech anxiety, ethical speaking, and listening skills. It then moves into the preparation stages, with detailed chapters on audience analysis, choosing a topic, conducting research, and organizing the speech content. The final sections of the book focus on delivery, covering vocal techniques, body language, and the effective design and use of visual aids. A key feature of the textbook is its practical, hands-on approach. It includes numerous practical exercises, real-world examples, and checklists to help students apply the concepts. The goal is to provide a user-friendly and comprehensive resource for developing public speaking competence.

Title: Introduction to Art: Design, Context, and Meaning
content: This open textbook offers a foundational introduction to the visual arts, designed for art appreciation or art history survey courses. The book is structured around three core areas of inquiry: design, context, and meaning. The first part of the book introduces the formal elements of art (such as line, color, and shape) and the principles of design (such as balance, rhythm, and proportion), providing students with a basic vocabulary for analyzing artworks. The second part emphasizes the importance of context, exploring how the historical, cultural, and social environments in which an artwork is created shape its form and function. This section provides a brief chronological survey of major art historical periods. The third part of the book focuses on interpretation and meaning, introducing students to different approaches to analyzing what an artwork communicates. It aims to help students move beyond simple description to engage in critical interpretation. The textbook is designed to be accessible to students with no prior background in art, providing them with the tools to understand and appreciate the visual arts from a variety of perspectives.

Title: A Guide to Making Open Textbooks with Students
content: This guide is a practical resource for college and university instructors who are interested in engaging in 'open pedagogy' by involving their students in the creation of Open Educational Resources (OER), specifically open textbooks. The book provides a step-by-step framework for managing such a project, addressing both the pedagogical benefits and the practical challenges. It covers all stages of the collaborative process, from the initial planning and scoping of the textbook project to strategies for effective student collaboration. The guide offers advice on the writing, editing, and peer-review processes, providing models for how to structure these activities within a course. It also covers the technical aspects of publishing, including formatting, licensing (using Creative Commons licenses), and disseminating the final product. The central argument of the guide is that co-creating a textbook with students can be a powerful form of active learning, giving students a sense of ownership and a deeper engagement with the course material. It serves as a comprehensive manual for educators looking to embark on this innovative teaching practice.

Title: Introduction to Logic and Critical Thinking
content: This open textbook provides a foundational introduction to the principles of logic and critical thinking. It is designed for introductory-level courses in philosophy or critical reasoning. The book aims to equip students with the skills necessary to analyze, evaluate, and construct arguments effectively. The text covers the core topics in the field, beginning with the fundamentals of argument analysis, teaching students how to identify premises and conclusions and to distinguish arguments from non-argumentative passages. It then provides a detailed treatment of deductive reasoning, including categorical logic and propositional logic, and introduces methods for testing the validity of deductive arguments. The book also covers inductive reasoning, exploring different types of inductive arguments (such as arguments from analogy and generalizations) and the criteria for evaluating their strength. A significant portion of the textbook is dedicated to the study of common logical fallacies, providing numerous examples to help students identify flawed reasoning in everyday discourse. The goal is to enhance students' ability to think clearly and critically about the information they encounter.

Title: College Success
content: This open textbook is a comprehensive guide designed to help students, particularly those in their first year, navigate the challenges of college and develop the skills needed for academic and personal success. The book covers a wide range of practical topics that are essential for a successful transition to higher education. Key areas of focus include academic skills, such as effective time management, study strategies, note-taking techniques, and test preparation. The textbook also addresses broader personal development topics, including goal setting, motivation, and maintaining personal health and wellness. Recognizing the financial challenges many students face, it includes a section on financial literacy, covering topics like budgeting and managing student loans. The book is written in an accessible and encouraging tone, with numerous self-assessment exercises, checklists, and practical tips. The overarching goal is to provide students with a holistic toolkit of strategies and resources to help them thrive in the college environment and beyond.

Title: Communication in the Real World: An Introduction to Communication Studies
content: This open textbook provides a broad introduction to the academic field of communication studies. The book is designed for introductory-level courses and aims to provide students with a comprehensive overview of the theories, concepts, and contexts of human communication. The text is structured to cover the major subfields within the discipline. It begins with foundational concepts of communication theory and then explores different communication contexts in detail. This includes interpersonal communication (the study of communication in relationships), small group communication (examining dynamics in teams and groups), and public speaking. The textbook also covers the study of mass media and its effects on society, as well as communication in professional and organizational settings. By covering this wide range of topics, the book aims to demonstrate the relevance and applicability of communication studies to a variety of real-world situations, from personal relationships to professional careers and civic engagement. It provides students with a solid foundation for understanding the complex role of communication in shaping human experience.

Title: University Physics Volume 1
content: This OpenStax textbook is the first volume in a three-part series designed for a standard two- or three-semester calculus-based physics course. This volume is intended for the first semester of the sequence and focuses exclusively on classical mechanics and waves. The book is structured to provide a rigorous foundation in the principles that govern the motion of macroscopic objects. It begins with foundational topics such as units, vectors, and kinematics (the description of motion). It then delves deeply into dynamics, covering Newton's laws of motion, work and energy, momentum and collisions, and rotational motion. The final section of the book introduces the physics of oscillations (like springs and pendulums) and mechanical waves, including sound. The textbook integrates calculus throughout, making it suitable for students in science and engineering majors. It includes numerous worked examples, conceptual questions, and a wide range of end-of-chapter problems to help students develop both a conceptual understanding and strong problem-solving skills.

Title: University Physics Volume 2
content: This OpenStax textbook is the second volume in a three-part series designed for a standard two- or three-semester calculus-based physics course. This volume is typically used in the second semester of the sequence and covers the topics of thermodynamics, electricity, and magnetism. The first part of the book is dedicated to thermodynamics, exploring concepts such as temperature, heat, the kinetic theory of gases, and the first and second laws of thermodynamics. The remainder and majority of the book provides a comprehensive treatment of classical electricity and magnetism. This begins with electrostatics (electric charges, fields, and potentials), moves on to electric currents and circuits, and then covers the principles of magnetism and electromagnetic induction, culminating in Maxwell's equations. The textbook is mathematically rigorous, utilizing calculus to develop the physical concepts. It is designed for science and engineering students and includes a wealth of pedagogical features, such as worked examples and extensive problem sets, to support student learning.

Title: Workplace Software and Skills
content: This OpenStax textbook is a practical guide designed to equip students and professionals with the fundamental computing skills required in a modern corporate or office environment. The book focuses on hands-on proficiency with widely used productivity software suites. It provides detailed, step-by-step instruction on the basic functions and common applications of both Microsoft 365 (including Word, Excel, and PowerPoint) and Google Workspace (including Docs, Sheets, and Slides). Beyond specific software applications, the textbook also covers broader foundational topics in information technology. This includes chapters on computer hardware components, the basics of computer networks and the internet, and file management. A significant component of the book is its focus on the ethical use of technology in the workplace, covering issues such as data privacy, security, and responsible online conduct. The textbook aims to be a comprehensive resource for developing the digital literacy and practical software skills that are essential for success in today's workforce.

Title: U.S. History
content: This OpenStax textbook is designed to cover the full chronological breadth of United States history, making it suitable for a two-semester introductory U.S. history survey course. The book aims to provide the necessary depth on key topics while ensuring the overall course is manageable for both instructors and students. The narrative covers American history from the pre-Columbian era to the present day. The textbook is structured to be flexible, allowing instructors to adapt the material to their specific course needs. It emphasizes a balanced approach, covering political, economic, social, and cultural history. A key feature is the integration of primary source materials and a focus on historical thinking skills, encouraging students to analyze evidence and consider different interpretations of the past. The book seeks to present a narrative that is inclusive of the diverse peoples and perspectives that have shaped the American experience. Its goal is to provide a comprehensive, accessible, and cost-free resource for learning about the history of the United States.

Title: World History Volume 1, to 1500
content: This OpenStax textbook is the first volume of a two-part set designed for a standard introductory world history survey course. This volume explores the vast expanse of human history from its origins up to the year 1500. The book is built around a commitment to a truly global perspective, moving beyond a Eurocentric narrative to give balanced attention to developments in Africa, Asia, the Americas, and Europe. A central pedagogical feature is its strong emphasis on the use of primary sources, which are integrated throughout the text to allow students to engage directly with historical evidence. The textbook also explicitly teaches historical thinking skills, focusing on core concepts such as causation, context, and interpretation. It encourages students to think critically about how historical narratives are constructed and to understand history not as a collection of facts, but as an ongoing process of inquiry. The goal is to provide a rich, multi-perspective account of the world's diverse past before the early modern period.

Title: World History Volume 2, from 1400
content: This OpenStax textbook is the second volume in a two-part series for introductory world history courses. This volume covers the modern era, exploring human history from approximately 1400 to the present day. Like its predecessor, the book is designed with a strong emphasis on maintaining a global perspective, examining the interconnected histories of societies in Asia, Africa, the Americas, and Europe. It avoids a purely Eurocentric viewpoint by highlighting the agency and experiences of diverse peoples across the globe. The textbook is structured to help students develop critical historical thinking skills, with a focus on concepts of causation, change over time, and the interpretation of evidence. It heavily incorporates primary sources into the narrative, allowing students to directly analyze the materials from which history is written. The book covers major global themes of the modern era, including the age of exploration, colonialism, industrialization, world wars, decolonization, and globalization, providing a comprehensive and accessible survey for undergraduate students.

Title: Astronomy 2e
content: This OpenStax textbook, now in its second edition, provides a comprehensive introduction to the field of astronomy. It is designed for introductory astronomy courses for non-science majors. The book defines astronomy as the study of the objects that lie beyond planet Earth and the processes by which these objects interact with one another. A central theme of the textbook is that science is a 'progress report'—a dynamic and evolving process of discovery rather than a fixed body of facts. The text traces the major evolutionary processes that have shaped the universe, from the Big Bang to the formation of galaxies, stars, and planetary systems. It covers a wide range of topics, including the history of astronomy, the tools of the astronomer (telescopes and spectroscopy), the properties of stars, the structure of the Milky Way galaxy, and the study of other galaxies and cosmology. The book is written in an engaging and accessible style, aiming to foster a sense of wonder and a scientific appreciation for the universe.

Title: Biology for AP® Courses
content: This OpenStax textbook is specifically designed to meet the scope and sequence requirements of a typical two-semester Advanced Placement® (AP®) Biology course. The book provides comprehensive coverage of the foundational research and core biological concepts that are central to the AP® curriculum. A key organizing principle of the textbook is its evolutionary lens; it presents biological concepts and the diversity of life through the framework of evolution, which is a major theme of the AP® Biology course. The text is structured to align with the AP® Biology Curriculum Framework, covering the four 'Big Ideas' of the course. It includes in-depth discussions of topics such as biochemistry, cell biology, genetics, molecular biology, evolution, ecology, and physiology. The book is rich in pedagogical features, including connections to AP® test questions, inquiry-based lab activities, and features that highlight current research in the field. The goal is to provide a high-quality, cost-free resource that fully prepares high school students for the AP® Biology exam.

Title: Chemistry: Atoms First 2e
content: This OpenStax textbook, now in its second edition, offers an alternative approach to the standard introductory chemistry curriculum. As the title suggests, it follows an 'atoms first' sequence. This means the book presents topics of atomic and molecular structure much earlier and in greater detail than the traditional approach. The rationale for this structure is to provide students with a solid microscopic foundation before moving on to macroscopic properties. By understanding the structure of atoms and molecules first, students are better equipped to understand subsequent topics like stoichiometry, bonding, and chemical reactions. The textbook is designed to link these foundational structural topics to all subsequent chapters, creating a more cohesive and logical narrative. It aims to help students see the connections between the subatomic world and the observable chemical properties of matter. The book covers all the standard topics of a general chemistry course and is suitable for a two-semester sequence, providing a robust foundation in the application of quantitative principles to chemistry.

Title: Organic Chemistry
content: This OpenStax textbook is a version of the renowned organic chemistry text by John McMurry, known for being one of the most clearly written and student-friendly books available for the subject. This open version is designed to meet the scope and sequence of a standard two-semester undergraduate organic chemistry course. The book follows a functional group approach, which is a common way to organize the vast amount of material in organic chemistry. This approach introduces different families of organic compounds (alkanes, alkenes, alcohols, etc.) one by one, discussing their structure, nomenclature, properties, and characteristic reactions. This edition has been updated to include new scientific discoveries and contemporary applications of organic chemistry, making the material relevant to students interested in medicine, biology, and other fields. The text's reputation is built on its logical explanations, high-quality illustrations, and extensive set of practice problems, all of which are designed to help students master this challenging subject.

Title: American Government 3e
content: This OpenStax textbook, now in its third edition, provides a comprehensive and engaging introduction to the American system of government. It is designed for introductory courses in U.S. government or political science. The book covers the foundational principles of American democracy, the dynamics of political behavior, and the structure and function of the institutions of government. Key topics include the Constitution, federalism, civil liberties and civil rights, political parties, interest groups, elections, the media, Congress, the presidency, the bureaucracy, and the judiciary. A central focus of the textbook is to encourage meaningful engagement with the material. It includes features that connect the concepts to students' lives and to current political events, aiming to foster a deeper understanding of the political process and to encourage civic participation. The book is written to be accessible and to provide a balanced overview of the complexities of American government, making it a valuable resource for students beginning their study of the subject.

Title: Introduction to Anthropology
content: This OpenStax textbook is a comprehensive introduction to the discipline of anthropology, designed for introductory undergraduate courses. The book adopts a 'four-field' approach, providing balanced coverage of the major subfields of anthropology: cultural anthropology, archaeology, biological anthropology, and linguistic anthropology. A key feature of this textbook is its commitment to integrating diverse voices and perspectives into the narrative. It actively includes case studies and examples from a wide range of cultures and highlights the contributions of scholars from various backgrounds. The text is built around several meaningful themes that are woven throughout the chapters, such as the experiences of Indigenous peoples, the dynamics of social inequality, and the application of anthropological knowledge to real-world problems. To promote active learning, the book includes engaging field activities and prompts for critical reflection. The goal is to provide students with a rich and holistic understanding of the study of humanity in all its diversity.

Title: Introduction to Political Science
content: This introductory chapter from OpenStax's 'Introduction to Political Science' textbook sets the stage for the systematic study of politics. It explains the relevance of political science in everyday life, emphasizing how understanding its core concepts can empower individuals to become more informed and engaged citizens. The text outlines the book's structure, which covers fundamental principles of political systems, ideologies, behaviors, and institutions. It aims to provide students with the analytical tools needed to comprehend the complexities of political events and to participate more effectively in political processes. The content is designed to be accessible for students new to the subject, laying a foundational knowledge base for further study.

Title: Contemporary Mathematics
content: The introductory section of 'Contemporary Mathematics' by OpenStax introduces students to the practical applications of modern mathematical concepts. The initial focus is on set theory and the use of Venn diagrams as a primary tool for visualizing relationships between different groups of data. This foundation is presented as essential for understanding subsequent topics in statistics and probability. The text emphasizes problem-solving and critical thinking, aiming to demonstrate the relevance of mathematics in various real-world scenarios beyond traditional algebra and calculus. It is structured to be engaging for a broad audience, including those not majoring in mathematics, by connecting concepts to everyday life.

Title: Abstract Algebra: Theory and Applications
content: 'Abstract Algebra: Theory and Applications' is a comprehensive open-source textbook designed for junior and senior undergraduate students. The text provides a rigorous introduction to the core principles of abstract algebra, covering groups, rings, and fields. A key strength of the book is its extensive collection of exercises, which range from computational problems to more theoretical proofs, allowing students to solidify their understanding. It also includes numerous non-trivial applications, demonstrating the practical relevance of abstract algebraic concepts in fields like computer science, physics, and chemistry. The book is structured to be suitable for a one- or two-semester course.

Title: A First Course in Linear Algebra
content: 'A First Course in Linear Algebra' is an open-source textbook that offers a comprehensive introduction to the subject. The text is organized around a core set of topics, including systems of linear equations, vector spaces, linear transformations, determinants, and eigenvalues. It is written with a strong emphasis on theoretical understanding and proof-based problem-solving. The book is known for its clear explanations and rigorous mathematical approach, making it suitable for undergraduate students majoring in mathematics, engineering, and the physical sciences. It includes a wide variety of exercises and is designed to build a solid theoretical foundation for more advanced studies.

Title: GetGenome: Overcoming inequalities in access to genomics technology
content: This research paper discusses the significant global inequalities in access to genomics technology, which has become essential for life sciences research. It introduces GetGenome, a non-profit organization established to address this disparity. The organization's mission is to provide researchers, particularly in low- and middle-income countries, with equitable access to genomics tools, resources, and training. By fostering international collaborations and building local capacity, GetGenome aims to democratize genomics research, enabling scientists worldwide to contribute to advancements in areas like global health, agriculture, and biodiversity. The paper outlines the organization's model and its potential impact on creating a more inclusive and equitable global scientific community.

Title: Symbiotic revolutions at the interface of genomics and microbiology
content: This paper explores the transformative impact of modern genomics on the study of symbiosis in microbiology. It argues that new technologies and research paradigms are fundamentally shifting long-held tenets in the field. The author highlights how genomic data is revealing the intricate and pervasive nature of symbiotic relationships across the tree of life, challenging traditional definitions and classifications. The paper calls for a more open-minded and data-driven approach, urging researchers to reconsider historical concepts of symbiosis in light of new evidence. It suggests that this 'symbiotic revolution' is leading to a deeper understanding of evolution, cellular biology, and the interconnectedness of life.

Title: Parental Support During College: A Comparison of Autistic Students to Neurotypical Students and Students with Other Disabilities
content: This is a forthcoming research paper that will investigate the nature and impact of parental support for autistic college students. The study plans to compare the types and levels of support received by autistic students with that received by their neurotypical peers and by students with other disabilities. The research will likely explore how different forms of parental support relate to key outcomes such as college adjustment, academic success, and overall well-being for these student populations.

Title: Obscured Inequity: How Focusing on Rates of Disparities Can Hide Conflicting Resource Inequalities
content: This paper presents a critical argument about the methodology of studying social disparities. It contends that focusing solely on rates of disparities (e.g., the rate of a negative outcome in one group vs. another) can be misleading and can obscure the underlying inequalities in resources that drive these outcomes. The author argues that this narrow focus can lead to a misinterpretation of the root causes of social problems and, consequently, to the design of ineffective or misguided policy solutions. The paper calls for a more holistic approach that analyzes both outcome rates and the distribution of resources.

Title: Autistic Traits and College Adjustment
content: This study examines the relationship between the level of autistic traits and various dimensions of college adjustment within a general sample of university students. The research investigates how traits associated with autism spectrum disorder correlate with academic performance, social integration, and mental health outcomes (such as anxiety and depression). The findings contribute to a better understanding of the challenges faced by neurodivergent students in the higher education environment, suggesting that autistic traits, even at sub-clinical levels, can impact the college experience.

Title: Making and Measuring Change in the Food System: The Perspectives of Funders
content: This paper explores how philanthropic organizations and funders involved in the food system conceptualize and measure social change. Through interviews and analysis of funder documents, the research investigates the strategies, metrics, and theories of change that guide their investments. The study sheds light on the challenges funders face in evaluating the impact of their support for initiatives related to food justice, food sovereignty, and sustainability. It provides insight into the priorities and evaluation frameworks that shape the allocation of resources within the food movement.

Title: Fit Around the Farm: A Holistic Approach to Health Promotion for Elders
content: This study evaluates a novel, farm-based health promotion program designed for older adults. The research analyzes the program's holistic approach, which integrates physical activity, social engagement, and connection with nature to improve overall well-being. The findings suggest that engaging elders in farm-related activities can lead to improvements in physical, mental, and social health. The paper highlights the potential of such non-traditional, community-based programs to provide meaningful and health-promoting experiences for aging populations.

Title: Experiences of Moral Distress in a COVID-19 Intensive Care Unit: A Qualitative Study of Nurses and Respiratory Therapists in the United States
content: This qualitative study explores the profound experiences of moral distress among frontline nurses and respiratory therapists working in a COVID-19 Intensive Care Unit (ICU). Through in-depth interviews, the research identifies the key sources of this distress, including witnessing immense patient suffering, dealing with resource limitations, and navigating difficult end-of-life situations with families. The paper also documents the coping mechanisms clinicians employed to manage the psychological burden, providing critical insights into the mental health challenges faced by healthcare workers during the pandemic.

Title: Digital Humanities and Digital Skills in the Future of Work
content: This is a forthcoming textbook that will explore the intersection of digital humanities and the evolving labor market. The volume is expected to address which digital skills, often cultivated in digital humanities research (e.g., data visualization, text analysis, network analysis), will be most valuable in the near future. It will also examine how the broader trends of digitization and digitalization are changing the nature of work and scientific inquiry itself, and how humanities education can adapt to prepare students for this future.

Title: Essays on Longtermism
content: This is a forthcoming book of essays focused on the ethical philosophy of 'longtermism.' This view posits that one of our highest moral priorities should be to positively influence the long-term future of humanity or sentient life. The book is expected to cover the various philosophical arguments for and against this position, explore its practical implications for decision-making today (e.g., in relation to climate change or AI risk), and address common objections and critiques of the longtermist perspective.

Title: Shared Metrics, Shared Progress: Insights from Harmonized Data on Poverty and Inequality In Caribbean Countries
content: This forthcoming World Bank brief will analyze newly harmonized household survey data from six Caribbean nations. The goal of the harmonization is to allow for more accurate cross-country comparisons of poverty and inequality. The report is expected to present core poverty and inequality statistics, examine the demographic and economic characteristics of poor households in the region, and discuss the implications of these findings for developing more effective and targeted social policies.

Title: Who on Earth Is Using Generative AI? Global Trends and Shifts in 2025
content: This forthcoming World Bank paper will analyze global adoption patterns for the 60 most-visited consumer-facing generative AI tools up to mid-2025. The research aims to track the explosion in usage, identify key market trends and competitive dynamics, and, crucially, reveal the stark global divides in adoption. The paper will likely shed light on how access to and use of this transformative technology varies across countries with different income levels and digital infrastructure, providing data on the emerging 'AI divide'.

Title: Female Employment in Ukraine
content: This forthcoming World Bank note will examine the impact of Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine on female employment. The analysis is expected to reveal how the conflict has affected gender gaps in the labor market and occupational segregation. The report will likely argue that the war has persisted and in some cases deepened pre-existing gender inequalities, which are driven by entrenched gender norms and the unequal distribution of care responsibilities, exacerbated by the conditions of war.

Title: Continuous Free Cortisol Profiles in Healthy Men: Validation of Microdialysis Method
content: This study is the first to validate a rapid sampling microdialysis method for measuring free cortisol, the biologically active form of the stress hormone, in both subcutaneous tissue and blood plasma of healthy volunteers. The research demonstrates the method's effectiveness by showing the dynamic responses of both total and free cortisol levels following pharmacological stimulation and suppression tests. This validated technique allows for more detailed, real-time investigation of the dynamics of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, with potential applications in endocrinology and stress research.

Title: LLM-Enhanced Reinforcement Learning: A Survey
content: This paper presents the first comprehensive survey of the emerging field that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) into the Reinforcement Learning (RL) paradigm. To structure this new domain, the authors propose a novel taxonomy that systematically categorizes the different ways LLMs can be used within the classical agent-environment framework of RL. This includes using LLMs for reward shaping, policy generation, and world modeling. The survey provides a valuable resource for researchers by organizing existing work and identifying key trends and open questions in this rapidly advancing area of AI.

Title: Introduction to Reinforcement Learning
content: This paper provides a concise yet thorough overview of the field of Reinforcement Learning (RL). It covers the core concepts and methodologies that define RL, offering clear explanations of fundamental components such as states, actions, rewards, policies, and value functions. The paper is intended as an introductory resource for those new to the field, summarizing key algorithms and providing a roadmap of resources for further, more in-depth learning.

Title: Variational Quantum Circuits Enhanced Generative Adversarial Network
content: This paper proposes a hybrid quantum-classical architecture for a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN), termed QC-GAN. The novelty lies in the generator component, which consists of a quantum variational circuit paired with a single-layer classical neural network. This quantum generator is tasked with creating data that can fool the discriminator, which is a traditional deep neural network. The research explores the potential for quantum circuits to generate complex data distributions that may be difficult for classical GANs to model, representing an investigation into the near-term applications of quantum computing for machine learning.

Title: Synthetic Brain Images: Bridging the Gap in Brain Mapping with Generative Adversarial Model
content: This work investigates the application of Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Networks (DCGANs) for generating synthetic medical images. Specifically, the research focuses on producing high-fidelity, realistic MRI slices of the human brain. The generator network is trained on a dataset of real brain scans and learns to synthesize new, artificial image slices that are statistically similar to the training data. This technology has the potential to augment limited medical datasets, which can be used for training diagnostic AI models while helping to preserve patient privacy.

Title: State of Geographic Access to Cancer Treatment Trials in the United States
content: This study reveals significant geographic disparities in access to cancer clinical trials across the United States. The analysis shows that the majority of U.S. counties have limited or no local access to trial offerings. This disparity is particularly pronounced in counties that are nonmetropolitan, have high levels of social vulnerability, and experience high cancer mortality rates. The findings underscore a critical equity issue in cancer care and research, and the authors call for concerted efforts to facilitate the participation of more diverse and geographically distributed sites to promote equitable access for all patients.

Title: Large language models in medicine: A review of current clinical trials
content: This systematic review analyzes the landscape of current clinical trials investigating the applications of large language models (LLMs) in healthcare. The authors identified 27 relevant trials (5 published, 22 ongoing) and categorized them into four main clinical application areas: direct patient care (e.g., patient communication), data handling (e.g., summarizing clinical notes), clinical decision support, and research assistance. The review provides a valuable snapshot of the emerging evidence base for LLMs in medicine, highlighting the areas where research is most active and where more investigation is needed.

Title: The role of Open Access Data in democratizing healthcare AI
content: This article argues that Open Access Data is a crucial element for democratizing the development and benefits of artificial intelligence in healthcare. The authors contend that making large, diverse health datasets openly available can enhance research, spur innovation, and prevent the concentration of AI development in the hands of a few large corporations. Using Andalusia, Spain as a case study, the paper discusses how open data policies can improve patient well-being and promote treatment equity by allowing a wider range of researchers and institutions to build and validate AI tools.

Title: Exploring the rise and diversity of health and societal issues that use a public health approach
content: This scoping review identifies and categorizes the wide range of health and societal issues for which a 'public health approach' has been advocated in literature published since 2010. The authors identified 28 distinct categories, including topics like violence, addiction, and obesity. A key finding is that while the term 'public health approach' is used widely, its operationalization varies extensively across different fields. The review highlights a lack of a consistent definition, which can lead to ambiguity in policy and practice, and suggests a need for greater clarity on what this approach entails.

Title: Social science to accelerate coastal adaptation to sea-level rise
content: This scoping review explores how various disciplines within the social sciences are contributing to research on coastal adaptation to sea-level rise. The analysis shows that fields such as Political Science, Economics, Sociology, and Geography are already making significant contributions by studying governance, economic impacts, community vulnerability, and spatial planning. However, the review also finds that other relevant social science fields are less developed in this specific context. The paper argues for a more integrated and comprehensive social science perspective to accelerate the implementation of effective and equitable coastal adaptation strategies.

Title: A Smol Perspective: Internet Sociolinguistics and the Border Between Written and Spoken Word
content: This paper argues that the nature of communication on the internet complicates the traditional linguistic distinction between written and spoken language. Using examples from online discourse, the author demonstrates how features typically associated with spoken language (e.g., informality, turn-taking, use of prosodic cues through emojis and punctuation) are prevalent in written internet communication. The analysis suggests that online language often occupies a hybrid space, blurring the boundaries and demonstrating that the line between these two modes of communication is more muddled and porous than previously understood.

Title: The Value of the Humanities: Understanding the Career Destinations of Oxford Humanities Graduates
content: This report presents a detailed study of the career outcomes for over 9,000 humanities graduates from the University of Oxford. The findings challenge narrow views of the value of a humanities degree by demonstrating that graduates enter a wide range of sectors and professions. The report confirms that the skills conferred by studying humanities subjects—such as critical thinking, complex communication, and cultural understanding—are highly valued by employers and can transform both individual working lives and the wider world. The study provides robust evidence for the economic and social value of humanities education.

Title: Public Access to Scientific Research Findings and Principles of Biomedical Research
content: This editorial from the JAMA Network discusses the journal's policy regarding public access to scientific research findings, particularly those funded by government agencies. The piece outlines the rationale behind the policy, aligning it with the core principles of biomedical research, which include the broad and timely dissemination of knowledge to accelerate scientific progress and improve public health. The editorial reflects the ongoing dialogue within scholarly publishing about balancing the sustainability of journal operations with the public good of open access to research.

Title: Peer reviewers from low- and middle-income countries for open access journals in oncology
content: This paper addresses the systemic impediments that researchers from low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) face in cancer research and publication. It specifically notes that article publishing charges (APCs) for open access journals are often unaffordable, creating a barrier to dissemination. The authors argue that actively engaging peer reviewers from LMICs is a crucial step towards a more equitable and diverse scholarly ecosystem. This practice not only provides valuable perspectives but also integrates LMIC researchers more fully into the global scientific community, helping to break down existing hierarchies in knowledge production.

Title: From data strategy to implementation to advance cancer research and cancer care
content: This paper outlines the importance of a comprehensive data strategy within a cancer center to improve both research and patient care. It discusses the entire data lifecycle, from systematic data collection in clinical practice to advanced analysis. The authors highlight the use of Natural Language Processing (NLP) to extract structured information from unstructured clinical notes. They also address the critical need for secure and ethical data sharing strategies to facilitate collaboration while protecting patient privacy. The paper argues that an effective data strategy is essential for evaluating clinical practices, understanding disease biology, and ultimately developing better treatments.

Title: Cardiology researchers' practices and perceived barriers to open science: an international survey
content: This paper presents the results of an international survey of researchers who publish in cardiovascular journals regarding their perceptions and practices related to open science. The findings reveal a complex landscape of attitudes. While many researchers support the principles of open science, they face significant barriers to adoption. The survey found that access to funding—specifically, funding to cover article processing charges (APCs) for open access publication—was perceived as the most essential incentive and the largest barrier to adopting open science practices. This highlights the economic challenges that hinder the transition to a more open research culture.

Title: Role of open access echocardiography in detection of cardiac structural and functional abnormalities
content: This study evaluates the clinical utility of an 'open access' echocardiography service, where general practitioners (GPs) can directly refer patients for cardiac ultrasound without a prior cardiology consultation. The research aimed to determine the prevalence of significant structural heart disease in the referred patient population. The findings show that major structural and functional cardiac abnormalities are common in late middle-aged patients referred by GPs. This suggests that open access echocardiography is an effective tool for the early detection of cardiac disease in the primary care setting.

Title: Imaging Neuroscience opening editorial
content: This editorial announces the launch of 'Imaging Neuroscience,' a new non-profit, open access journal. The journal was founded by the former editorial board of the established journal 'NeuroImage.' The authors explain that this move was a direct response to the publisher's (Elsevier) high article processing charges (APCs), which they deemed 'unethical and unsustainable.' The launch of this journal represents a significant event in the academic publishing world, highlighting the growing tension between commercial publishers and academic communities over the costs and control of scholarly communication, and a move towards community-led, 'diamond' open access models.
